If you've not played this game before, you need to play it. It's ridiculous amounts of fun, which is a testament to id software's expertise at turning out astonishingly playable games that hold up even 20(!) years later -- even the controls feel "modern" (first-person shooter games pretty much still use Quake II's controls scheme). This is a steal for £4 (£9 if you also grab the mission packs, which are recommended).

Once you buy this, go download a "source port" (I used kmquake2) which will let you play in on modern systems, with widescreen support and improved graphics (for instance,  shadows, dynamic lights, and high-res texture support). You will have to download the hi-res textures if you want them, but the game was perfectly playable in HD (1920x1080) even without them. Obtaining a source port isn't too complicated and guides are available.

One downside of this Steam version of Quake II, as far as I can tell, is that the game's music isn't included. Quake II has a lot of ambient sound so this wasn't a big problem for me, but some may be annoyed at not obtaining a crucial piece of the game. Various workarounds do exist but some may be annoyed about why the music wasn't included in the first place.

Even without the music though, the game will give you hours of fun. Highly Recommended.

[b]El apartado sonoro me parece una de las más grandes bazas del juego[/b]. Mientras que el Quake original únicamente contaba con sonido ambiental que siempre sonaba igual, Quake 2 nos deleita con [b]geniales temas metal[/b] que nos proporcionarán auténticos subidones mientras disparamos a toda velocidad. Ya solo gracias a este apartado, Quake 2 me parece [b]mil veces más dinámico[/b] que el Quake original.

Jugablemente es bastante similar, aunque nos encontramos con un [b]elenco totalmente nuevo de armas y enemigos[/b]. También debo decir que los enemigos de Quake 2 me parecen [b]muchísimo menos molestos que los del original[/b], aunque estos han perdido su estética "lovecraftiana".

Pero no todo es perfecto en Quake 2, ya que a mi parecer, su gran fallo son [b]sus brutales backtrackings[/b]. Supongo que para evitar hacer el juego tan lineal, a los desarrolladores se les ocurrió alejarnos del camino principal de cada nivel haciéndonos ir a otras partes separadas de este buscando/activando cosas. Lamentablemente, el tiro les salió por la culata, ya que [b]como el juego no tiene minimapa, por culpa de esos backtrackings nos perderemos muchísimo y estaremos deaumblando durante grandes ratos sin saber muy bien qué hacer.[/b] Este me ha parecido [b]el fallo más gordo y que más me ha sacado de quicio del juego.[/b]

En cuanto a duración, [b]dura una media de 5-6 horas[/b] (más o menos como el original).

En definitiva, Quake 2[b] opino que barre a su antecesor en prácticamente todo[/b]. Obviando lo del asqueroso backtracking, se me ha hecho en general, un juego [b]mucho más dinámico, divertido y ameno.[/b]

 W przeciwieństwie do pierwowzoru, twórcy zrezygnowali z mrocznego klimatu, zombie, zamczysk itd... , w zamian postanowili "urzec" graczy futurystycznym światem. 39783594.review:
Ah [i]Quake II[/i]. The follow up to one of the biggest games of 1996, [i]Quake II[/i] is a FPS made by genre masterminds Id Software and was originally released exclusively for the PC on November 11, 1997 though throughout the next 20 years, got ports for systems like PlayStation, N64, Xbox 360 (as a bonus for the original release of the 360 port of this game chronological follow up [i]Quake 4[/i]), and even the Zeebo (even [i][b]I[/b][/i] don't know what that is). Despite its title however, it has very little to do with the original [i]Quake[/i] outside of gameplay mechanics. In fact, the main reason for its title is because every other name Id Software had come up with was already taken in some shape or form.

Now which was a first for Id Software, the game has a pretty detailed story which is actually told as the game goes on rather than having everything stuff into the manual and the occasional intermission with a few paragraphs of text. The basic story is that you're a marine called Bitterman and are part of an invasion force sent by the governments of Earth during a war with a warlike empire known as the Strogg, a race of cyborgs that use the corpses (and anyone unlucky to get captured) of their enemies to survive. The invasion is meant to be as payback when the Strogg invaded Earth (something that is only partially explored story-wise in the much much later released prequel [i]Enemy Territory: Quake Wars[/i]). Of course since this is an Id Software game from the 90s, everything goes horribly wrong when the humans suddenly discover that the Strogg just happen to have a big fucking EMP gun. Which causes everyone's drop pods to come crashing down. Thankfully though, Bitterman (i.e. you) is alive and not captured and so just became Humanity's hope for ending the war. 

Now the game is pretty much typical of any Id Software game from the 90s. Fast-paced movement, a crap ton of hostiles with no allies (or in this case, any allies that can fight) in sight, and the only thing stopping them from giving you a quick and painful death (and turning you into one of them) are some big guns and lots and lots of bullets and plasma. Though in this case, you also go along completing objectives as you work your way to shutting down the Strogg war machine and eventually taking on the Strogg's leader itself, the Makron.

Running on the Quake II engine (also known along with it's [i]Quake[/i]'s engine as Id Tech II), this game pretty much is gonna run on any modern system like a hot knife through butter. Which definitely tells you how good Id Software was and still is at their jobs from a technical standpoint. Also the music is [i][b]fantastic[/b][/i] (though the music's gonna be put in on your own as the Steam release much like the first game lacks). With tracks by Sonic Mayhem, the soundtrack shows that traditional attitude Id Software had in the 90s when it came to their games.

Overall Quake II is worth the time and is cheap for $5 US.

39661689.review:
Quake II is an intense aftershock, even two decades later.
(Full disclosure, I've been playing this game on and off sense I was a kid - so I'll attempt to keep rosetinted views at a minimum).

Quake II is a game that is pretty deeply ingrained into my taste as a gamer. I love fast and furious FPS games, I love frantic metal and techno soundtracks (and metal music full-stop) and I love the grimy dirty oppressive sci-fi backdrop to everything, the whole game is very much a callback to the violent power fantasies of Doom (the soundtrack is a hallmark evident of this) and a large departure from the bleak smothering and hopeless air to the original Quake, which many find to be a downside. Although to be straight forward, I prefer the sci-fi outings of Quake 2 over the Lovecraftian depths and deprecated infernal hallways of Quake 1, not to dssmiss it, as I enjoy that game as well, just not AS much as Quake II

Having played any of iD's previous offerings, or any 90s era FPS - you know the score. This time around you're a badass space marine hellbent on destroying the Strogg war machine by taking out the Big Gun, a planetary defense weapon capable of keeping the planet Stroggos totally impenetrable.
The intro cutscene shows you barreling towards the planets surface and ending up way off course and far away from your intended target, from then on out, you carve a bloody warpath to the Big Gun. Upon destroying it, you are then ordered to hunt down and elimate the Strogg leader, the Makron and upon doing so - save Humanity.
Pretty standard stuff, barrel chested walking death machine protaganist facing off against likewise towering antagonist and his armies of random mooks. 

The gameplay comes to what you'd expect from a 90s FPS - you get a sci-fi tinged aresnal this time around to aid in blasting\fragging\liquifiying the new threat. Instead of Nail-Guns and Thunderbolts this time around - you're armed with Chainguns, Railguns and Hyperblasters and instead of decimating Eldritch horrors you're dispatching horrible amalgomations of flesh and metal - the Strogg. To put it plainly, the game is a sci-fi take on the original formula, calling from the original Quake - you know what to expect. The level design is a different take to the original, as opposed to singular episodes you have 'Units' that are essientally large levels seperated by 'airlock's with different objectives. 
One level may involve you hunting down for a certain weapon, or obtaining a Commander's Head to access a new area, things of that nature, and it helps to puncuate the otherwise simple nature of the game and it's card-hunts, which the game still has, it strikes a good balance. 

Beyond that, the game doesn't essientally bring a lot new to the table. Quake II is a take of the original formula and throwing into a sci-fi setting and giving it an equally fitting soundtrack to go along with it, which, like the Quake I Nine Inch Nails offering I find very much required to get the full effect. 

The Multiplayer, as expected - is sublime - very much what one would expect from an iD FPS. Weapons have utility, maps all 'flow' and can almost be liked at like race tracks where a central path runs through it and side paths and 'shortcuts' adorn them to keep things fast and frantic. Nothing but positive experiences and nothing short of high recommendation in that regard. The only iffy point with this can be the player 'weight', in the original Quake you felt nearly weightless but here you feel like you've got a bit of stone to your step, which may turn others off, as the momentum needed to get to top speed is a bit of an issue for some. I personally don't mind it, although I felt like this was worth mentioning anyway. It's also still VERY MUCH alive, even 2 decades later.
Now THAT is some longevity, and is ABSOLUTE proof of the quality of the Multiplayer component.

Okay, with all that being said, Quake II on Steam is missing the soundtrack and is somewhat incompatabile with newer systems. Simply download Yamagi Quake 2, download the soundtrack and throw it in the install directory and your good to go. Check the Steam Guides on this to get some more details, but it really is as simple as drag and drop.
Quake II also had two Mission Packs released for it, and without going into detail on those - I enjoy them (The Reckoning anyway, I haven't completed it as of the writing of this review) but I have completed Ground Zero and it is a frustrating messy smattering of spaghetti level design and an all around unfun experience. If inclined, these have problems running on new systems but are easily fixed with a launch option edit, but it won't track playtime for the specific Mission Packs as it'll be ran IN Quake 2 as opposed to it's own client. I was very annoyed upon finding that THIS is the ONLY solution to playing them otherwise, I would've reviewed the Mission Packs on their own but, whatever.

Yeah, 100% recommended. Both to the FPS fan of yore and the FPS fan of now.

It might seem weird to review this in 2018 but Quake II remains one of my favourite and most played games and I'd be remiss not to at least give a few kind words. It's certainly dated graphics-wise, but compared to other games of the time, nothing really comes close in terms of  fast pace and ultra-fast movement that you just don't get elsewhere and while most people will have started with, and love Quake 1, for me it was Quake II- I play it every few years from start to finish and haven't found many other games as satisfying and well put together.

Is it worth picking up these days? Absolutely. I'm coming from a place of nostalgia but few games age better than id software titles, and even fewer let you jump it and play and get to grips with the brutal weapons and maps so quickly while still offering some challenge. There are admittedly some technical complaints from others but again, for me, it's always been one of the games I can install on any new computer and be literally be playing within a minute or two of purchase and one that friends and new faces love to watch and try for themselves.

The soundtrack and level design deserve special mention as they tie together wonderfully. To this day Quake II is one of the few games that makes me tense and scared while playing and perhaps it's laughable but the 4 legged guys jumping out of dark corners and the silent deformities when you turn corners still make me crap myself despite knowing the maps as well as the back of my hand, and the game deserves credit for that.

I'm still working through this game as of writing this, as I've gone through roughly 3 PC changes in the last few years.

Not to beat around the bush, but I do view Quake 1 as the superior game of the two (and yes, I do know about the naming issues making this game a sequel in name only). In spite of that, and some other minor complaints, this is one of my "unwinding" games, untainted by nostalgia.

I never played Quakes 1-3 as they came out; I never had a PC powerful enough, and I was always more in the Doom camp, Doom II being the very first FPS and "proper" PC game I ever played. However, after buying Quake 1 a while back, I immediately defected and wrote a glowing review for it. 
             Quake II, after the brilliant Lovecraftian mishmash that was 1, feels a bit strange to get into, especially after playing some more modern FPS's made after the genre had had more of its kinks ironed out. Level design, especially during portions of the game you're expected to retread levels with only a vague sci-fi-warehouse name that you're supposed to find after picking up the key item, is a particularly prickly bit for me. Luckily, it makes up for it with both tone and basically everything else.
             Quake 1 had a heavy, oppressive, almost hopeless, sense of being a tiny human in an interdimensional grand plan orchestrated by an eldritch monster that neither understood nor particularly cared about you or your guns. That's all well and good, but Quake 2 completely eschews that (and in doing so, avoids tiring out the first game's premise) for run-gun-bunnyhop-rocketjump gameplay that pits your Lone Space Marine against an evil expansionalist society of nightmarish cyborgs. Serious series tonal shift? Yes. Good thing? Also yes.
              
If you're a fan of Quake 1, or really any '90s shooter, give this a try. If you dislike wonky series discontinuity throughout a franchise, you're gonna have a bad time.

As a VERY IMPORTANT side note, the game still relies on CD audio, which Steam doesn't include in this release. I STRONGLY recommend either using a 3rd party engine that supports the downloaded soundtrack files, like QuakeSpasm, or an analogous program to the Ultimate Quake Patch (for Quake 1), which patches in the music tracks and appropriate looping for you.

Quake 2 is one of my favourite FPS games from the '90s. It is nice to see it available in a digital format and playable even after 20 years of its release. Naturally, the graphics look quite dated but there are dozens of mods out there ready to provide you with the necessary remedy.

I remember using the Railgun here which became a franchise favourite (hardcore gamers always wanted to use this in Quake 3 against the A.I.-controlled bots). Also, from Doom the BFG weapon was included as perhaps the most devastating weapon in our assortment. As for the levels: objective-based they are and we have lots of wide, open areas. And finally some cutscenes explaining what is going on. 

Forget Quake's dark fantasy environment and welcome a sci-fi milieu where mankind is fighting the Strogg civilization. I can't help but think of Star Trek's Borgs whenever I see some of the game's enemies. Our hero is the sole survivor of a crash and since he crash-lands at a key location on the Strogg home planet his superiors entrust him with solving their little problem once and for all. The title has nothing to do with the entity encountered in the 1st episode - the name was not changed as keeping the word made sales better.

Quake 2 had a fast-paced gameplay with really cool music (here non-existent, unfortunately, similarly to the issue experienced in Quake 1) and a long-lasting single player experience. A must-have classic and - for me - the best in the franchise.

38243165.review:
I played through the campaign on hard mode.
I played on the mod KMQuake2 because it supports widescreen and high-fps. 
(Hence the low amount of registered gameplay)

I really enjoyed playing this game. I will just mention my impression of the game here.

Gameplay is very well-balanced.  It keeps almost all the good things from Quake 1 in terms of weapons and pickups, and except for a few flaws, it is very well-done.There are a wide variety of enemies, that do not only range from weak to tough, but often have specific quirks and strenghts/weaknesses. This makes tactical gameplay possible. The typical progression is at hand in the campaign: Enemies are getting tougher, but you get also stronger weapons and resources. Also, for those unfamiliar with Quake 1, the game also features a heavier, more ammo-wasting weapon and a weaker, more ammo-preserving weapon for most types of ammo, which I really like. A cool new thing is that enemies dodge some of the stuff that is coming at them, which works pretty okay.

What I truly love about Quake 2 is that it really manages to balance things in a way that it is hard, yet fair. Actions have consequences, and that makes for particularly good gameplay at times. For example, I had a fight on an open field where I was very low on health, and I had a ton of ranged enemies coming at me. I recognized I was going to be in trouble, fled into a small, unknown corridor, fought one guy there and get health- and ammo-pickups, enabling me to recover and fight from a much more advantaged position because these enemies were quite clunky. However, some other enemies (like the berserker) would have been much more dangerous in small corridors. This way of fighting yourself out of situations is very cool to do and adds another layer to the gameplay.

Some minor cons about the gameplay are: 
The removal of the airstrafing as seen in Quake 1, which makes movement less enjoyable.
Throwing grenades doesn't work well, so find a grenade launcher
Some enemies will shoot at you from great heights, resulting in you being very randomly shot from annoying places
On the other hand, enemies really don't  know how to deal with players attacking from a higher place.
Boss fights are a bit anti-climactic and often easier than some small hordes of usual enemies.

The game is aesthetically very different from Quake 1. Quake 2 chooses for a futuristic setting with some relatable places, instead of the more abstract gothic-style interdimensional setting from Quake 1. Graphically, I'd say Quake 2 is an improvement, with more detailed environments in general. 

The level design is generally well done. Quake 2 features 'hub-gameplay': The game sometimes lets you run back and forth between places to hack systems, unlock keys, and other stuff, which can set off alarms and alerts more enemies on the way. The game definitely feels more relatable to a real place because of this. One minor con is that you sometimes have to figure out where to go and run around in desolate places because you killed every enemy already. There are still plenty of secrets, and the game lets you use the environment in fights, for example you can sometimes lower bridges to let enemies burn/drown instead of directly fighting them. There is a paperthin storyline in the game, but you can just as well ignore that.

NOTE: THE STEAM VERSION DOES NOT CONTAIN A SOUNDTRACK AT ALL! 
I personally was not bothered by this, but I know the removal of the soundtrack is a bad thing for this version. Just putting it out there.

TLDR: Weapons/ammo/pickups similar to Quake 1, gameplay well-balanced & fair, yet challenging, Quake 2 has a science-fiction setting with more relatable places, and improves slightly on graphics.  The game lets you free in the way you play and is very enjoyable.

38214338.review:
Прошёл в очередной раз Quake 2, и вдруг захотелось сделать обзор. Как раз и повод есть — игре стукнуло 20 лет, юбилей.

В девяностых id Software были богами компьютерных игр, весь мир играл в их шутеры и покупал ради них новые компьютеры. Не стал и исключением Quake 2. Но всего через год вышел Half-Life и оттеснил место Quake 2 в сердцах игроков. Все знают Гордона Фримена, но мало кто помнит солдата Биттермана (да, у главного героя Quake 2 есть имя — обернитесь в начале игры). Заслуженно ли? Я считаю, что нет. Что есть такого в HL, чего нет в Q2? Сюжет? Да он же в HL ничем не отличается от первого Doom — случилась непонятная фигня, повылазили черти из порталов, наш герой берёт кучу стволов и убивает всё живое на протяжении всей игры. Или вам нравится нездорово большое количество одинаковых учёных и охранников, которые обожают встать у закрытой двери, долго что-то лопотать и не пропускать вас дальше? Лично я предпочитаю игры без капитанов прайсов. Может, многие любят полчаса ехать в вагончике, чтобы начать игру — ведь это крайне кинематографично и сегодня игра — не игра, если сразу пустит вас в себя играть?

Кто-то рассказывает про якобы невероятную инновационность халф-лайфа, когда шутер состоит не из отдельных карт, а разделён на локации, составляющие один здоровенный уровень, по которому можно свободно перемещаться. Для меня очевидно, что эти люди никогда не видели Quake 2, где есть всё это, и даже в большей степени, чем в Half-Life. Здесь постоянно нужно возвращаться на пройденные карты и искать предметы или кнопки, позволяющие пройти дальше. Сколько раз я проходил Quake 2, но до сих пор то и дело туплю, теряюсь в больших уровнях Америкэна МакГи и подглядываю в прохождения. Жаль, что в графическом плане уровни выглядят одинаково и скучно. Сплошные серые военные базы почти всю игру, и лишь ближе к концу, во дворце финального босса, в игре появляются цвета. В этом смысле даже более старый первый Quake лучше, там каждый эпизод — это новое измерение, отличающееся от остальных. Впрочем, половину халф-лайфа вы проведёте в вентиляционных шахтах, что ничуть не увлекательнее.

Из чего ещё состоят игры? Музыка? В Q2 — бодрый музон, подгоняющий игрока и смолкающий только тогда, когда из уровня пора уходить насовсем. В HL музыка играет лишь по большим праздникам. Искусственный интеллект? В HL он неплохой, но и в Q2 не так прост. Как и в Doom, можно исхитриться и заставить одних противников воевать против других. Оружие? В Quake 2 оно внушительнее, мощнее, патронов для любого дают много. Самое известное оружие Q2 — рэйлган, самое известное оружие HL — гвоздодёр. Что из этого круче? Вот именно.

Короче, если вы хотите поиграть в стрелялку того времени, когда игры уже начали делать чем-то более сложным, чем сборником отдельных уровней, то не ограничивайтесь лишь тем, что подарил нам Габен. И, конечно, не бросайтесь играть в то, что Габен выдаёт в стиме за Quake 2. Обязательно сначала скачайте музыку в формате ogg и какой-нибудь порт игры (я предпочитаю Yamagi Quake II — он в активной разработке, не искажает, но улучшает оригинал, есть масштабируемый HUD, работает мультиплеер).

Также есть два дополнения, которые, в общем-то, почти ничем не отличаются от основной игры. Парочка новых видов оружия и врагов и новые, но не менее серые уровни. Хотя второе дополнение, Ground Zero, мне не понравилось. От нового оружия там больше вреда, чем пользы, враги слишком живучие, а потому скучные, и жутко бесят туррели на каждом углу. Они маленькие, в них сложно попасть, сложно сломать, но сами они очень мощные и стреляют без промаха. В каждую новую комнату заходишь, а там, блин, штуки четыре туррели. И так всю игру. Говорят, разработчики аддона позднее приложили руку к Aliens: Colonial Marines, что многое объясняет. А первое дополнение, The Reckoning, хорошее, играть можно. В мультиплеер Quake 2 тоже сыграйте с друзьями, он веселее мультиплеера многих современных игр.

36352643.review:
Another game I recall from my childhood that I never really got very far into it. It sounds bizarre saying this, but my mom actually beat this game while she had time to burn in between jobs. I was more or less scared to get killed in any fps game, so I avoided it. Later on, I had a nostalgia for this game and so I swiped it after it was on sale. For about $2, it's hard to avoid purchasing.

So, let's start with the pros for late 2017:
-Still holds up in its single player campaign; pacing is good; doesn't particularly get boring
-Hard mode is the right difficulty. Sometimes you wonder why the Gladiators have such ridiculously accurate railgun blasts, so if you're like me and you want to keep reloading a save until you don't get hit by them at all, this might be a bit annoying, but all in all, there is nothing here that I would consider unfair or any spikes in difficulty
-Lots of guns; requires rationing of ammo types and thought about which weapon will work in which situation and enemy
-Variety of enemy types; AI is acceptable
-Secret areas, which most modern games completely lack
-Campaign is quite long

Cons:
-Hitting an enemy in the face seems to have no apparent difference to hitting them in their hand
-Sometimes you will find an area in which an enemy cannot move and you can just fire safely from your location using your blaster.
-Graphics look dated, but I am sure there are mods out there that can really fix this
-Color palette is drab. Like seriously drab. After about 10 hours through, you really feel a bit claustrophobic in terms of light and color, like you just want to escape to the surface. In a way, that is this game's strong point as the Strogg stronghold/ship is bleak and sterile, but it does become a pain as a player. I also had this problem to some extent when playing Resistance: Fall of Man, which had a very limiting color palette and was also aiming for bleakness in a hostile alien world, but that game had a more compelling story for an fps and remains more memorable to me despite that issue. That said, it probably owes something to games like Quake II and Half Life 1/2, so we can thank the makers of Quake.
-Story is basically irrelevant. It's good enough to get you through the game, but that isn't saying much. It really amounts to you single-handedly massacring an entire Strogg stronghold. And it's unclear who these guys are. They're this strange cyborg race in between man and machine, though it's not clear how exactly they stay alive if they're still biological organisms or what their purpose is, since they all seem intent on one thing, which is to kill you. Since they only seem to be doing someone's bidding, I can only assume they are under the control of a more intelligent sentient overlord. Only the end boss explains nothing and is just more of the same old same old. Speaking of which....
-End boss is really lame. You can basically stand behind a pillar, use any of your weapons when you step around the pillar, and then jump back behind the pillar while he starts blasting it
-Some of the weapons lack a bit of punch for what they are. The grenade launcher and rocket launcher in specific. This isn't a big deal though.
-Inventory UI isn't developed, so you often forget what items you have and what key you need to use any of them. I barely used any item on hard.

There are other issues with it that you can probably overlook, but something that does stand is its linearity. From this point of view, it's a standard fps. Barebones story to get you through the game, you're by yourself, you shoot the enemy, somehow you manage to kill about 1000 Strogg and their boss all by yourself and then you escape their fortress. But it's still a decent fps gameplay-wise.

Recommended if you like a solid fps, but can ignore a practically non-existent story. It was a reasonably enjoyable romp through memory lane for me personally, but it really isn't even a must-play for somebody who enjoys fps games, let alone games in general. If like me, you were curious how some of these 90s fps games you grew up playing held up now, it's worth looking at, but even then, there are plenty of good fps games that I would choose over this one.

35945656.review:
DISCLAIMER: I never played this back in the day. Why? I was 3 years old when this came out. I have no nostalgia for this game. 

I played this for the first time a few years ago (around 2014), got to near the end, and despite enjoying it I somehow didn't finish this. Fast forward to a few days ago; I decided to start another playthrough, and have just completed the game a few hours ago. 

Quake 2 was some of the most fun I've ever had in a single player FPS. It may even be THE MOST fun single player FPS I've played to date, and I've played and enjoyed the original Quake, both DOOM 1 and 2, Bungie's Halo games, Unreal, and the Half Life series among others. 

Quake 2's gameplay is fast paced with very satisfying gunplay that, combined with the soundtrack, creates a constant feeling of raw power. The Super Shotgun, the Chaingun, the Grenade Launcher, the Rocket Launcher, the Rail Gun and the BFG10k are the best (and my most used) weapons in the game. The sound design and feedback of these guns are what makes the gameplay so good in conjunction with strafe-jumping at high speeds and gore-ing your enemies while doing so. The game's variety of enemies can be reduced to chunks of meat and metal depending on what weapon is being used, how close you are to them, and how many bullets you decide to empty into them. 

The game is not without its downsides: 

- You will sometimes find yourself lost and without enemies to slaughter. This is due to the lack of an in-game map that shows you your current position and where you need to be going. Instead, there's only a mission objective screen that can be opened by pressing [TAB] that gives two brief and shallow descriptions of your location and what to do. This is a strange step back considering there was a directional map in the first two DOOM games. Wandering around without enemies to gore can really make the game turn into a drag. 

- Some of the weapons become useless or boring to use and feel like wasted inventory space and potential, specifically the Blaster (although this is the starting weapon), the regular Shotgun, the Hand Grenades and the Hyperblaster. Despite the Machine Gun being just the smaller version of the Chaingun, it still serves a purpose since you can control your rate of fire and conserve ammo better than the Chaingun, so I won't lump it in with the other lackluster weapons. The Hyperblaster was another weapon I didn't like to use mainly because of the sound and projectile appearance making it feel like a peashooter. When compared to the Plasma Gun in DOOM 1+2 and Quake 3, it doesn't hold a candle to how fun those were to use.

- The soundtack is great but repetitive. 

Wrapping this up, I haven't been able to play any of id Software's new entries for Wolfenstein or DOOM 2016 yet (and I've heard and seen very good things) so I'll hold some reservations. Having played and completed Quake 2 in conjuction with seeing a lot of footage of DOOM 2016, I can see the influence that Quake 2 has on DOOM 2016. With Quake 2 not being an actual sequel to the original Quake, now taking place in an entirely Sci-Fi setting, I couldn't help but think that this felt more like a DOOM sequel despite originating as a new IP. If I haven't conveyed enough how timeless the gameplay is and unquestionably still holds up, it feels like playing DOOM 2016 on very low settings. Again, I have yet to actually play DOOM 2016, but the gameplay looks almost identical despite Quake 2 being 20 years old now. 

Maybe that speaks to how last gen's console-oriented FPS titles took a lot of aspects backwards. Thankfully games like DOOM 2016, the new Wolfenstein games and even Titanfall 2 are proving that the PC versions of these games don't have to be compromised for consoles and their controller-based input methods, nor do they have to look at what Call of Duty is doing. 

TL;DR: Play Quake 2. Especially if you played DOOM 2016. Fast paced combat, satisfying gunplay and brutal, high speed violence makes this my favorite single player FPS game to date.

35835774.review:
Bien qu'il en porte le nom tout désigné, Quake II n'est pas une suite de Quake mais un nouveau jeu situé cette fois-ci dans un univers futuriste. L'ambiance est militaire, industrielle et la bande-son métal. Avec cette orientation de design, Quake perd beaucoup de son charme par rapport au premier épisode mais reste efficace de bout en bout. Le moteur est une évolution de celui de Quake I : certains murs sont désormais destructibles et les niveaux sont organisés en hubs. Deux ajouts très pertinents qui donnent du liant à cet univers mais qui ne sont pas des nouveautés puisque ces deux aspects étaient déjà présents dans HeXen II, basé quant à lui sur le moteur du premier Quake. La vraie nouveauté technique se situe dans la gestion des lumières colorées. A l'époque de Quake I, l'utilisation des cartes 3D relevait du domaine de l'expérimentation mais l'accélération 3D est ici pleinement prise en compte. Fin 1997, passer du mode software au mode de rendu accéléré sur une 3Dfx donnait vraiment l'impression de jouer à un autre jeu ! Un classique du FPS tout à fait recommandable.

NOTE : comme pour Quake I, la release Steam ne contient pas la BO... Utiliser un moteur moderne (Yamagi par exemple) et ajouter les fichiers sons est à nouveau requis pour profiter totalement du titre.

La première extension The Reckoning nous met dans les bottes d'un autre soldat largué sur Stroggos en même temps que le héros de Quake II. Après un début pénible, The Reckoning revient à des niveaux proches de ceux du jeu original avec les bons et mauvais côtés que cela implique. Les affrontements sont rapides et furieux mais les décors sont redondants, alignant les couloirs et les hangars plein de caisses... Les nouvelles armes sont réussies (à défaut d'être nombreuses) mais les nouveaux ennemis sont des évolutions de ceux de Quake II. Ils compensent leur faible inventivité en matière de design par des dégâts et une résistance accrus. Finalement c'est cette augmentation de la difficulté qui relance l'intérêt de cette extension. The Reckoning injecte un peu de tension par rapport à Quake II mais innove trop peu.

La seconde extension Ground Zero est clairement de meilleure facture surtout du point de vue des niveaux qui sont beaucoup plus travaillés que ceux de The Reckoning. Ils exploitent bien le principe des hubs et sont largement plus intéressants à parcourir. Les nouvelles armes se révèlent par contre très classiques (avec même un nailgun revenu de Quake I). Comme de nombreuses reviews l'ont déjà signalé, le gros souci se situe au niveau des nouveaux ennemis. Les tourelles du jeu posent un problème dans le sens où elles apportent beaucoup plus de frustration que de challenge. Petites, elles sont donc difficiles à viser et infligent cependant des dégâts considérables. Elles forcent à avancer prudemment ce qui est tout le contraire de la philosophie d'un Quake ! Si je ne devais recommander qu'une seule des deux extensions, je choisirais quand même Ground Zero car moins ennuyeuse grâce à ses niveaux bien conçus.

[h1]Quake Never Die[/h1]
Нестареющая классика. Яркий пример того, каким должен быть шутер от первого лица. Тут есть всё, что нужно для получения удовольствия, а также для развития тактических и практических навыков стрельбы, которые без сомнения пригодятся в других шутерах. В отличие от первого Quake, в котором порой надоедало обилие вездесущих Огров и некоторая затянутость отдельных уровней, в Quake 2 Id Software пошли другим путем. 

[h1]Надаём врагам по рогам за Землю матушку.[/h1]
Уровни во второй части более компактны по размерам, расстановка врагов стала разнообразнее, так, что нет явного перекоса в сторону одного-двух видов врагов, которые будут появлятся чаще остальных на протяжении всей игры. 

[h1]Расчехляем арсенал.[/h1]
Оружие, которое присутствует в игре полностью оправдывает своё наличие, и мы будем использовать любое из них в зависимости от ситуации в течение всей игры, бесполезных пушек нет, даже бластер пригодится в качестве фонарика. Также  по настоящему удобной фишкой стал инвентарь, приберечь Квад или Защитный костюм, для подходящей ситуации - что может быть лучше. 

[h1]Громче музыка - красочнее битва![/h1]
Отдельной похвалы заслуживает саундтрек, к сожалению нещадно вырезанный из стим версии, так что приходится использовать порты чтобы играть с музыкой. Саунд бодрый, поднимающий боевой дух, под который устраивать геноцид Строггов одно удовольствие. 

[h1]Что написано пером - прострелено шотганом.[/h1]
Сюжет в игре не блещет изысками, но, ведь как говорил[quote=John Carmack]Сюжет в игре - как сюжет в порнофильме. Он должен быть, но он не так уж важен.[/quote] Тем не менее он тут присутствует, что делает наши блуждания по техническим и научным комплексам Строггов не бессмысленным  истребление противника, и вполне обосн6ованным исполнением долга по спасению Земли. Итак подробнее по плюсам и минусам:

[h1]Ну-с, что тут у нас вышло?[/h1]
[b]Плюсы:[/b]
+ Идеально сбалансированный геймплей который даже на высокой сложности интересен, и доставлет массу удовольствия.
+ Разнообразные враги, каждый из которых требует свою тактику, иначе, если переть под пули не думая, есть риск уйти  с поля боя в качестве дуршлага, а то и вперед ногами.
+ Интересные уровни, разбитые на сектора, будь то лаборатории, заводы, шахты, или дворцы Главзлодея, как правило по 4-5 уровней на эпизод, связанных схожим антуражем и общей конечной целью. Переодически мы возвращаемся из следующего уровня в предыдущий, но другими путями, что также добавлет интереса и разнообразия.
+ Саундрек. Выше всяких похвал, трудно представить другие треки сопровождающие нас по уровням Строггоса.
+ Инвентарь. Полезная штука. Собрать арсенал из разнообразных бонусов, и использовать в удобный для игрока момент - идеальный вариант. Больше не нужно подбирая руну учетверенного урона, ломиться скорее дальше по уровню чтобы усиление не пропало зря, и это здорово. Жаль такое в будущем не в каждом шутере встречалось. 
+ Оружие. Один из примеров того, что каждая пушка нужна, нет захламления бесполезными пукалками, от которых толку едва ли. Хотя лично мне не нравится здешний гипербластер, потому не использую его, храня заряды для Power Shield.
+ Секреты. Их много и они в большинстве очень полезные. Также имеются любопытные пасхалки, особенно та что на финальном уровне, кто играл тот поймет ;)
[b]Минусы (Конкретно стим версии):[/b]
- Вырезанный саундтрек. За что вы с ним так?
- Версия игры без поставленного на неё порта, может либо не запускаться на новых ОС, либо работать с проблемами. Но это встречается во многих старых играх в стиме, что приходится доводить до ума самостоятельно.
Итого: 9 из 10. Минус балл за стим версию, в игре хорошо абсолютно все, в который раз проходя дабы вспомнить как оно раньше было, получил массу положительных эмоций. [h1]Спасибо Id за отличную игру.[/h1]

You're stranded on a hostile alien world, everyone else is dead, and you have to destroy an alien overlord before they invade earth again. Time to bunny hop over everything.

Quake II is a release sequel to Quake but an actual sequel to Quake Wars but also a prequel to Quake 4. It's also older than both of those. 

The Terran Coalition of Man embarks on Operation Alien Overlord, a counter-attack on the alien race known as the Strogg, who apparently invaded Earth some time prior. The Strogg are a cybernetic race that fuse biological material with advanced technology. They apparently wanted humanities sweet succulent man meat for their own use. Oh baby.
But humanity did not want to give the alien invaders their man meat, and instead fought a war with the Strogg to save themselves from wiggly robot fingers. 

You play as Bitterman, the most bitter man in the universe. Bitterman's drop pod is knocked off course, which saves him from being destroyed or captured by Strogg and their really big gun. I'm serious, it's actually just called “Big gun.” 
Now, because Bitterman is a FPS protagonist, he becomes stronger with the less friendlies there are around him. So if lots of friendlies= COD protagonist, then Bitterman is somewhere along the level of  Lo Wang or Sam Stone.

I like Sam. 

Depending on who you ask Quake II is either a step down or step up from Quake. But if you ask me I would say it's a...Nice addition, I guess. 

Quake II does a lot of things better than Quake. Many of the guns are crunchier and have more punch than the Quake counter part. But at the same time the level design kind of took a hit, even if it makes a little more sense this time around. 

This game also has one of the best shot guns I have ever had the pleasure of using. It's just so useful in basically any situation and mulches almost every enemy you come in contact with. Quake II also has a lot more ammo to come across, so you get to use more of your weapons than just the grenade/rocket launcher and your two shotguns. 

Quake II's enemy design are some of my favorites from any game. With the Strogg chopping up people and using their parts to make more soldiers. Everything you run into is so macabre and grotesque. Even with their low poly count they're still just gross to look at. Their weapons are usually grafted to their body with little care for hygiene and appearance, so you get disgusting mix of human flesh and steel, which gets even worse when you take a look at some of the later enemies like the Parasite or the flyers. 

Like the original game, Quake II also has some different ways to play. There were a few console ports that ranged from “goofy lookin'” to “Pretty good.” 
The PS1 port plays like mud, but the N64 port is actually pretty passable. There was also the Dreamcast port which is apparently the definitive edition to play if you somehow don't have this on PC. 

You can also get some source ports that improve textures and graphics if somehow you can't tolerate those sweet sweet 1997 textures. Q2Pro is the most popular one, it's also the one I'd recommend. 

And just Quake 1, there are two mission packs that were released at a later date called “The Reckoning” and “Ground Zeroes” if you just can't get enough Quake II action. 

Like Quake 1, Quake II also has a very competent multiplayer. Quake II took a lot of the features from Qauke 1 and improved on them such as rocket jumping and bunny hoping, it kind of worked as the framework to what would be perfected in Quake 3. And just like Quake you can always find people down to play a few round of Q2 multiplayer. 


Quake II is also good, I'm just going to go ahead and tell you to play it. So go ahead and do that.

Quake II gets several uncomfortable uses of the phrase “man meat”  out of an arbitrary score system I don't use properly. 

Bats can see.

I remember Quake II as the first PC game I owned as a kid. I must have been about 11 years old and had previously played Doom & Doom II together with my dad (I was in charge of pressing the fire button).

The suspense of fighting the evil Stroggs on every corner of their military facilities is an experience that always stayed with me. 
It was also the first time I tried to make my own levels and got enthusiastic about the possibility of creating my own games some day (something which later became my profession). 

The one thing that really stood out for me about Quake II was the atmosphere. The game's aesthetic may not be a hit with everyone, but for me it was, and still is. The bleak rusty environments effectively instill feelings of dread and despair. 
The decision to go with organic/machine hybrids for the enemies is a smart one. We are able to identify enough with the characters because of their organic aspects. We can still recognize the humans and creatures they may one day have been. Yet at same time we are reminded of their cold and mechanical other-worldliness. As a plus, the modelers could get away with a lot more blockiness.

At some point I tried the Berserker mod, which updated the game with modern HD graphics, but while being prettier in a 'technical' sense, the graphics lost their consistency as the models remained blocky. In the end, it damaged the believably of the game world, rather than improving it. A lot of the bump maps were really noisy and didn't make any sense material-wise. They attracted attention to all the wrong elements. It ultimately made me realize how well the graphics were done in the original and how important it is to have a consistent aesthetic.

The levels are well designed, with tons of secrets and some smart use of back-tracking. The weapons and enemies are iconic and well placed throughout the maps. 

The sound FX and music for this game are simply amazing and I remember I would put the game disk in my stereo player, just to listen to the soundtrack. Which brings me to the rather disappointing fact that the music is missing in this Steam release. 
Despite this, it's still worth picking up this classic!

pros:

+ Good old classic shooter action
+ Great atmosphere and sound FX
+ Rock-solid game design
+ Iconic enemies and weapons

cons:

- The steam version requires some assembly (music and widescreen resolutions are not included)

32822778.review:
One of those classic FPS titles that I've been wanting to come back to for ages. So I did. How does it hold up?


The graphics are 1997. Really cool then (PARTICLE EFFECTS!), pretty basic now, but the art direction is mostly fine so it's not unbearably hideous. Unless you really can't stand low poly models with blurry textures.
One thing I don't like that can't really be excused by the game's age is the uninspired enemy design. A lot of enemies look really similar and bland, even the final boss just looks like some of the other stuff you've been killing for hours.
The environments aren't particularly varied either but I can live with that because a) it's a military compound, those are typically not built to look fancy, and b) they had to account for the hardware limitations of 1997 computers.

The audio design is a bit heavy-handed, with the then-standard enemy alert lines (which are always the same, too), narration by Microsoft Sam and the lines of your captured comrades being so repetitive and annoying that you'll probably just kill them so they shut up (and hey, they even drop items sometimes). Most guns sound (and look) powerful, making them satisfying to use.
The Steam version has no music for some reason, which is a shame.

The storyline (if you can even call it that) is simple - you've landed behind enemy lines and your job is to infiltrate their buildings and disable their crucial defence systems so the cavalry can come in safely. That's about all there is to it.

The gameplay is mostly what you'd expect from an oldschool shooter: run around, grab a lot of physically impossible guns and singlehandedly take on an entire alien army.
Some enemies are fairly challenging but if you observe their behaviour you can figure out how to deal with them efficiently.
This game hits just about the right amount of health and items in levels so it's not unforgivingly hard but you still need to be careful. You can (and should) use most guns quite liberally without running out so that's nice too.
There are secret areas in most (maybe all) levels, some easier to find than others. The stuff you get from them is not always that great, often you'll just get a new gun that you'd get your hands on two minutes later anyway.
In compliance with the 90s' standards for FPS games, the level design is a bit maze-like in places, sometimes you'll have numerous places to go and no clear indicator of where you should go first (other than a vague objective in the F1 screen), but it's not terrible. Levels are divided into interconnected maps, similarly to Half-Life.
I must say the final boss was really underwhelming. As long as you've saved up enough ammo (and hopefully quad damage) it's business as usual - dodge and shoot until it dies, no advanced strategy or anything. He doesn't look or act substantially more dangerous than most other late-game enemies.


So to sum up, it's a 1997 game with all the pros and cons of a 1997 game - dated graphics, somewhat awkward audio design, intense action broken up only by hunting for switches and keys. If you're into old FPS games and for some reason haven't played this one, go for it. If you prefer streamlined modern shooters with HD graphics, don't.

Even though I think Quake is a better game, Quake II is still one of my favorite shooters of all time and one that I played constantly as a kid, putting many hundreds of hours into it on both singleplayer and multiplayer. I recommend grabbing the Quake2xp mod from modDB. The gameplay will stay the same as the original, but the game's visuals and effects are heavily updated to be more modern (there are a few glitches but nothing gamebreaking that I've seen). This is a game that really started pushing the genre into the modern days with enemies who could evade your attacks, levels that had you going to different areas and then backtracking to various "hubs" to proceed to new areas, etc. At the same time though it retains the classic id software gameplay of fast paced combat, lots of gibs, and no reloading.

If you've never played it, do yourself a favor and give it a try, it still holds up very well today.

31311632.review:
Quake II is the sequel to Quake. Well, not really. It actually has nothing to do with Quake whatsoever, and they only kept the name for marketing reasons. However, it's still an Old-School FPS, and a very technically proficient one at that. The graphics were amazing at the time, and still look fine (if simplistic) today. It has pre-rendered cutscenes that're alright, and lots and lots of voice acting. It's also a good shooter, with plenty of weapon and enemy variety, solid sound design, and fast, cathartic gameplay. Like Quake, it has no use button and some really mazy yet intuitive level design. It also has the obligatory mid-to-late 90s inventory, which I never really got around to using. Quake II has no major flaws, and is a perfectly good way to pass the time.

However, that's all it is. Quake II works well, but it's also routine, pedestrian, and mostly unremarkable as Old-School FPS go. It's not outstanding and weird like DOOM or Quake, it's not bold and memorable like Duke Nukem 3D or HeXen, and it's not even irritatingly bad like Eradicator. John Romero had left id Software by this point, and his manic influence, whether it be for good or for ill, is sorely missed. Quake II has no major downsides, but no major upsides either. It is 90s FPS: The Game. I recommend it because even the most average 90s shooter is still completely worth playing, but be warned that this is no masterpiece like the ones id Software had produced before this.

Oh, and like Quake 1, you have to download a source port and a patch to get it to run correctly with music and everything on modern systems. You'd think that Steam would've fixed that by now.

Aaaah, Quake 2.... Oque falar de Quake 2?

Lançado em 9 de novembro de 1997, Quake 2 foi o jogo que me introduziu ao gênero FPS, e que me fez amar o gênero e a franquia Quake.
Me lembro que quando criança, eu tinha um cag*ço de jogar, pois eu realmente tinha muito medo daqueles inimigos, meio humanos meio máquinas, principalmente do Berserker que quando te avistava, vinha correndo pra cima querendo te socar até a morte, e do Parasite, aquele cyborg que lança uma língua ou um tubo sei lá em você, e suga toda a tua vida, além de dificultar a visão, porque a tela ficava totalmente vermelha e o personagem gritava igual um louco. Mas mesmo com todo este medo, eu adorava meter bala e projéteis de energia (principalmente com a BFG10k) nos inimigos. 
Quake 2 foi criado, pela ID Software (a mesma produtora de DOOM) e distribuído pela Activision. O game não é uma sequência de Quake. 

Você joga com um marinheiro chamado Bitterman que participa na Operação "Alien Overlord", uma tentativa desesperada para proteger a Terra de uma invasão alienígena, lançando um contra-ataque no planeta natal da hostil civilização cibernética Strogg, que nada mais é do que uma raça que mistura  várias epécies com implantes cibernéticos e que são controlados por uma entidade maior. A maior parte dos outros soldados são capturados ou mortos logo após a sua entrada na atmosfera do planeta, cabendo a você, adentrar o planeta natal dos Stroggs e assassinar o líder Strogg, Makron.
O jogo possui duas expansões, a [i]The Reckoning[/i] e [i]Ground Zeroes[/i], adicionando muitas coisas novas, como items, missões e histórias.

Até hoje existem muitos jogadores de Quake, principlamente por causa dos mods, que assim como o DOOM clássico, existe uma variedade enorme. E oque falar da trilha sonora? Meu amigo, a trilha sonora feita pelo Sonic Mayhem é sensacional e encaixa perfeitamente nas fases e atmosfera do jogo.

Quake 2 é 10/10

28459984.review:
Warning: This review will contain d**k sucking and circlejerking. Proceed with caution

Quake 2 is my favorite shooter. I love (almost) everything about it. From the opening level to the final boss there is always something that I appreciate and love every time I play. 

Progression is something that is important to me, a feeling of a changing world as your move through the game. Quake 2 is easily in a whole different world with this. Every "Unit" of the game is spearated into a hub world and connecting levels that you go through to complete a variety of objectives. As you continue through the hub world and complete the various objectives, the hub level changes. The best example is in the power plant Unit at the the half way point of the game. As you turn off the coolant for the reactor and turn on the pumps for the toxic waste the actual Reactor Factory you go through falls apart as you run quickly to the exit. It is honestly one of the most sastifying feelings knowing that you are literally changing the world as you go through it. The hub structure of the game does more than just provide a look into your progression, it also serves to make the world feel huge and expansive. From the mission briefing screen before you are put into the Unit until the exit button at the end of the unit it all feels like one huge level. Sure, there are loading screens throughout it but they are so small and come at predictable and understandable times that it makes everything feel seamless. 

The combat is also satisfying. The AI (While somewhat silly in some places) is suprisingly complex for the time. For example, the Berserker enemy will activley dodge your grenades that you throw at him (sure it hits him sometimes but he tries to dodge) and other enemies like the Enforcers duck from your bullets. The enemies also give out unique sounds so you know exactly who you are facing against, and if you are about to face them. For example, the parasite (a dog/spider hybrid looking freak) makes a very weird tapping sound while you are near him (but doesn't see you) so you can easily activley know that you will not only be facing a Parasite shortly, but also that he is hiding. With 11 weapons there is always something that takes out certain enemies better than others. This game even introduced the now legendary Railgun. 

The level design is top notch. Every Unit of the game (of which there are 10) have unique designs that let you know exactly where you are. Sure, they mostly are inside factory areas, however they all look different enough to let the player know exactly what point in the game they are at. For example, the Bunker unit (2nd) is a very storage facility type place with boxes everywhere and a very storage type feeling to it. Meanwhile the Power Plant unit (6th) uses very bright powerful colors to show that you are in a place that powers your target, Big Gun (one of the main objectives in the entire game) Secrets also litter the levels which give players goodies, some are harder to find then others but they are all imensly satisfying to find. There are even three levels that are hidden from the player, each varying in length but all have somthing unique about them, from low gravity to a very harsh timelimit to grab as much ammo as you can. 

The only issues I can thing of are the boss fights. There are 3 total bossfights in the game and they are all awful. The bosses do not have enough health to provide much of a challenge. The final boss is pitiful. After being built up as the "Big leader" of the Strogg the final boss, Makron, takes as much as 10 seconds to beat if you have the right weaponry (which you will since they bombard you with ammo before the fight) it really just seems slapped on and I would have much prefered other enemies there protecting Makron (Like in the 2nd expansion pack) or just a better boss fight (this too was fixed in the 2nd expansion pack)

The only other issue protains to the Steam release. The Steam release is the base game as it was in 1997 so the resolutions are low and the overall build of the game is dated. However, you can go online and find many source ports which fix the various issues with the game and allow you to customize it to fit your needs, Quake 2XP (my favorite), KMQuake2, Berserker, and others that I can't name off the top of my head. 

Do I recomend Quake 2? Hell yeah. It may not be as indepth as Half-Life or any modern shooter, however what is here easily surpasses most shooters in quality (so much so that this still remains my favorite over 15 years after I first played it)

28440701.review:
A classic FPS that is an entirely different beast from Quake 1. This game has more realistic weapon physics, which slow down gameplay compared to quake 1, but it still manages to be a fast paced "Run and Gun" shooter worthy of the Quake name. It features backtracking to previous stages, a more fleshed out story than a lot of the older FPS, and mission objectives, which were all new compared to ID's other classics. While having very little relation to Quake 1 and 3, Quake 2's story is continued in Quake 4 with a much more modern take.

The game hasn't aged well compared to many other classic FPS, including even Quake 1. The main issue being that many of the weapons just feel clunky. ID tried to emulate some realism this time around and added a lot delays, cooldowns, and recoil to the guns. It takes a few levels to get a feel for some of the weapons, but they work well enough. There is still a lot to love and respect about this game. 

tl:dr It's worth giving a shot if you like classic FPS from the early 3D era, or just want more background info on what happened before Quake 4.

26687840.review:
I'm honestly surprised I came out liking this. Sure, the Quake franchise is one of those venerable classics of FPS gaming, but I frankly hated the first one and this iteration didn't exactly leave a good first impression, as the first two chapters are exactly what detractors of Quake 2 always describe it as: boring, brown levels meandering vaguely with only the most basic indications of purpose with little story beyond "shoot the bad guys and reach the next area."

It's around the prison chapter that the game starts coming to life, the level design beginning to actually reflect the in-universe function of the areas instead of just being arenas to blow up jock-Borg in. Now I have context for what I'm doing here. Now I can care about moving forward instead of treating it like a data entry job with bullets instead of numbers.

After that point, the game doesn't exactly shine, but is nonetheless a solid package with decent weapon and enemy variety. Nowhere near my favorite games, but I wasn't bored and I wasn't overly frustrated. Given the game's fondness for exploration and backtracking, I suspect that if it were remade today, the chapters would be consolidated into continuous sprawling levels rather that chopped up into three or four segments each, and the game would be better for it.

Not much to say on this one, it's not anything special but it's still a competently assembled example of classic FPSes.

[h1]Quake II - игра эпохи[/h1]

[i] Сейчас мы живем в такое поколение, когда видео-заставки преобладают в шутерах, и регенерация здоровья является уже нормой. А что было сначала? А сначала был Doom. Затем Doom II... После чего, пришел ОН  - Quake. И в в 1997 году появляется самая культовая игра эпохи Quake II. Самый брутальный шутер, ибо по количеству мяса, на то время ему не было равных. Вкупе с крутым саундтреком, и нереально крутой графикой, лучше которой был только [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/kirillapollyon/recommended/13250/] Unreal[/url], все это сделало игру, в которую играют до сих пор. [/i]

Сюжет прост, как и в большинстве игр того времени - на Землю напали инопланетяне, и мы, будучи единственным выжившим бравым десантником, должны в одиночку сделать чуть меньше, чем все - а именно уничтожить оборону врага. Столкнуться придется с врагами всех видов, цветов и мастей. Противники довольно умные, на то время, впрочем, даже сейчас они выглядят очень достойно.

Арсенал оружия тоже очень впечатляет. Именно с Doom и Quake стал настолько каноничным набор - Пистолет, Дробовик, Двустволка, Автомат, Пулемет, Гранатомет\Гранаты, Ракетница, Плазменное ружье, Рельсотрон и БФГ(ну в последнем слоте чаще всего базируется любое очень мощное оружие, к примеру Пушка из Serious Sam"а). Настолько полезный и универсальный арсенал, который закрепился во всех последующих играх. Дизайн стволов нереально стильный, и отлично чувствуется в игре. Автомат имеет отдау(!!!), каждый выстрел Двустволки ощущается мышкой, ну и про БФГ я вообще молчу, тут и так все понятно))

Дизайн уровней проще, чем в первых двух частях Дума. Но зато интереснее. Мало того, что игра нелинейна, потому что периодически приходится возвращаться на уровни, которые проходил до этого, потому что там открылась нужная дверь. Да и всякие ключи\рычаги запрятаны тоже довольно глубоко и неочевидно. Это вам не консольные казуалочки, что щас выпускают. Тут все серьезно.

Если бы сделали Brutal Quake II, то, поверьте, он был бы в разы круче чем новый DOOM! Остается надеятся, что ID когда-нибудь перезапустят легендарную серию в виде Сингл-плеера, а не мультиплеерного шутана(которому хоть и нет равных по динамике, но не все в него играют).

[b] Игра олд-скул в чистом виде. Абсолютный и непревзойденный оригинал. Таких игр больше не делают. Мало того, что энтузиасты до сих пор(!!!) пилят моды на Quake, так и перепроходить Quake всегда интересно.[/b]
[b] Железно 10 из 10[/b]

What can I say about Quake II that hasn't already been said by a thousand others? Quake II is, quite simply, the finest first-person shooter ever crafted, and quite possibly the greatest game ever made. Deceptively simplistic, the single-player campaign never gets boring or tiring and when that's exhausted, there is the perfectly constructed multiplayer.

And after that? Probably close to ten thousand distinct mods and any of a hundred thousand or so add-on maps, player models, sound packs and so forth.

Quake II is certainly my all time favourite game. It has also stood the test of time: its graphics are still serviceable now and the original executable, programmed in 1997, will still run on a 64-bit Windows 10 machine. But that's not the end of it. Q2 has any number of source ports and high-resolution model and texture packs intended to bring the game's graphics and compatibility up to scratch on modern systems. The game is almost infinitely moddable and extendable, and it having been open sourced some years ago, anybody with some amount of programming skill can adapt it.

But even with all of that, I still find myself returning to vanilla Q2 deathmatch and single player. It really is the finest gaming experience I've ever known, on any platform.

Quake II is a fun game to come to when you want to experience the old-school gameplay again, but frankly it's quite short for games of its time. I'm thinking it's because of the new things introduced with the second iteration of the franchise.

First off let me say that Quake II has probably much more in common to the original Half-Life than the first ever did. From the feel to general looks, let me save you all the detail and sum it up as follows:

* Gameplay (the way the mechanics feel, not the get-bring-key concept we're all familiar with)
* Weapon models
* Lightning

Now it is highly probable that most of these changes originate from Half-Life (and the series, as a whole) using the same, modified engine but the similarities are obvious.

Gameplay-wise it is great, the battles feel great and some of the early weapons which could be considered obsolete after a certain point only become less useful, still allowing the player to take down several weak enemies spread throughout the level. The game doesn't forget what it started from and as soon as a new enemy is introduced it always appears throughout places.

The boss fight however is probably one of the most underwhelming fights I've ever seen. The story is only told through several cutscenes which are at most ambiguous and details which will need to be looked SPECIFICALLY for. It still allows, however, for some context of why you're shooting things up so it doesn't get boring.

I strongly suggest you play this with brightness to medium or as low as possible because the game looks infinitely better, from back in the day to even 2001 at some points, looking in places as better as Half-Life.

Overall Quake II is a fun old-school game though it is quite short and after the fun it's only mods that keep it alive. Other than the message at the end of each unit (I forgot to mention that levels are spread in units, semi-open world type) there's nothing cataloguing for whatever you've collected and it feels a little pointless to return and get the rest unless you plan to replay the whole game again.

24709435.review:
The generation of first-person shooters that followed the original Quake represented an enormous leap forward in many ways. Consider that in the span of a single year, from December 1997 to November 1998, the world saw the releases of Quake II, Unreal, and Half-life. This was also the first generation to support graphics accelerators (what we now simply call video cards) right out of the gate, which doubtless helped make the hardware an industry standard. Unreal and Half-life obviously brought new features to the table by virtue of being new IPs but Quake II advanced the traditional iD shooter experience in ways that can still be appreciated now.

One great leap forward from Quake is the presence of an actual plot, as well as gameplay that integrates with the story beats. Earth has been sucker-punched by the Borg's trailer-trash cousins the Strogg, and humanity elected to return the favor in fine Starship Troopers fashion. The delightfully 90s CG opening shows Earth forces in orbit around the Strogg's dirtball planet, raining drop-pods of hard-assed marines that get mysteriously wiped out. Your pod avoids destruction, landing far outside the enemy's nerve center, and it's up to you to frag an entire planet of cyborg things for the fate of humanity.

The way this plays out is in clusters of interconnected levels that you move between to complete objectives. Arriving at the Strogg supply depot, for example, you make your way to the upper levels of the Ammo Depot to access the Supply Station and Warehouse. The Warehouse is powered down so you head to the Supply Station, blow up the logistical train, and take power cubes back to the Warehouse to advance to the next hub. F1 brings up a helpfully succinct summary of your current objective so you know what to look out for while you blow Strogg into tiny meaty bits.

This, of course, is the meat of the game, blowing Strogg into tiny meaty bits. Here the game borrows from its lineage with high movement speed and vicious weapons that dismember your many enemies. There's a greater spread of guns than in the previous Quake, including classics like shotguns and launchers, callbacks to Doom like the chaingun and BFG, and a few new inventions like the railgun which itself has become iconic of the series. You have a wide array of options when approaching enemies, and the mix of foes in large battles can call for different weapons, especially once you factor in the varied terrain.

Your enemies follow a similar vein as the original Quake enemies in that they have unusual combinations of threats and quirks that must be learned. The Enforcer, a common chaingunner foe, can duck projectiles and fires wildly in certain death animations. The Gunner packs both a machine gun and a grenade launcher. You'll also face flying enemies, several flavors of melee enemies, a foe that can revive dead enemies, and more. Unlike original Quake all of these are thematically connected as Strogg, an alien race constructed from the biomass of other races (mainly human, it seems) and cybernetic enhancements. This theme is touched on not just in the monsters but in the levels themselves, with adventures through the Strogg factories where they are produced and reared.

And that's really the thing I want to commend Quake II for, the effort made to weave the storytelling into every aspect of the game. Levels aren't just halls and platforms to frag around, they're designed as recognizable, functional places for the Strogg war machine. You'll break captive marines out of prisons, sabotage power plants, and shut down factories of war. All of this is done under radio chatter from your side reporting on efforts underway, while you come across corpses of fallen marines almost every time you locate a new weapon or supply cache. It feels like a cohesive world you're besieging, made all the more compelling by the soaring, brutalist architecture and detailed, identifiable rooms.

The look and feel of Quake II is unique even now, and really deserves to be experienced. The palette for the game is surprisingly warm, with rich orange skies, red-flecked concrete, and glowing golden particles everywhere. Special effects rely heavily on the chunky particle system, giving lasers a visceral sizzle and the railgun a thick, gratifying trail of annihilation. Enemies burst into meaty chunks and aerosol sprays of blood with the smallest provocation. There's something quintessentially 90s about the whole presentation, almost like a Rob Liefeld comic book come to life. Your guns are huge, your enemies are weird and lumpy, and everything is over-the-top fast and brutal and saturated. It can be an intoxicating experience fragging through dense battles and leaving trails of gibs through the sprawling levels.

The only nits I can pick are similar to the technical issues Quake 1 suffers from, that the CD soundtrack is absent and you're not really going to be playing the multiplayer out of the box. Both of these can be corrected with a little research and modding, but unlike Quake 1 it's not really that necessary. Quake II was a huge landmark for multiplayer but the singleplayer campaign should not be ignored, for reasons I've rambled on enough about already. The graphics are plenty clean for their age (your Vaseline-smeared weapons aside) and the sound design is that special sort of unique that sticks in your mind years after the fact. I will freely admit a little bias here because I've finished the singleplayer multiple times and got my original FPS chops in the multiplayer, but if that's not an endorsement in and of itself I don't know what is.

24192879.review:
Quake II é um jogo de tiro em primeira pessoa (FPS), desenvolvido pela ID Software e publicado originalmente pela Activision (quem diria que a mesma se inspiraria nesse jogo para fazer os novos COD, huh? :P {zuerinha}), lançado no dia 9 de Dezembro de 1997. Originalmente lançado para Windows, ele ganhou ports para Nintendo 64, Playstation, Dreamcast, Xbox360 e Zeebo (sem bonus round dessa vez, sendo q ele sofre os mesmos problemas do Quake 1 que havia citado na minha análise do mesmo, com exceção da música, que sinceramente ficou tão boa quanto a versão de PC, e da dublagem, que sinceramente vcs vão querer ficar ouvindo a dublagem de BF: Hardline e MKX pro resto da vida :P). Ele é o segundo game da série Quake, embora esse n tenha nada haver com o primeiro.

O jogo usa a ID Tech 2, ou Quake II Engine (Quake II {duh}, Heretic II, Anachronox, Daikatana {Must not Memes :P}, etc), uma versão melhorada do motor gráfico do primeiro Quake (o q mais sofreu alteração aqui foi a iluminação). Entre os principais envolvidos no projeto, temos John Carmack (programador), Adrian Carmack (artista) e a incrivel participação de Sonic Mayhen (músicos). Esse foi o primeiro grande projeto da ID sem Romero, que estava produzindo Daikatana (Must... not... meme... John Romero's about to make you his bitc*). O jogo ganhou duas expansões: Quake II Mission Pack 1: The Reckoning e Quake II Mission Pack 2: Ground Zero (além de uma terceira, chamada Quake II Netpack I: Extremities, que é um pacote de mods vendidos oficialmente [Embora eu fico triste pelas pessoas que compraram isso, afinal todos os mods vcs podem achar pela internet :P]). As duas expansões contam com novas fases tanto singleplayer quanto deathmatch, mas aviso que elas n são tão boas quanto às expansões do Quake I eram (AAAAAHHHH TURRETS! -RIP Quake II Ground Zero; 1998 - Turret).

No jogo, você controla Bitterman, um soldado humano para lutar contra os Stroggs, uma espécie de aliens. Os humanos e estes aliens estavam em guerra, e como último esforço humano lançam um exército para Stroggos, o planeta deles, como parte da Operation Alien Overlord. Porém, a maioria do exército acaba morto antes de chegar na superfície graças a Big Gun, uma grande arma destruidora que impedia as tropas humanas de chegarem ao planeta. Você é um dos poucos que sai vivo, com o objetivo de cumprir as ordens enviadas por seus comandantes no territorio inimigo. As expansões contam com histórias paralelas a esta. O jogo funciona por unidades, cada unidade tendo várias fases que estão ligadas, muitas vezes te obrigando a voltar em lugares que vc já foi. Durante as fases, você tem um computador, que mostra suas missões durante as fases/unidades. Você deve ir pegando novas armas, ficar mais forte e seguir até chegar ao seu objetivo final.

O jogo possui 10 unidades (ambas as expansões contam com 5 unidades adicionais cada), além de 8 fases Deathmatch (The Reckoning adiciona 7 arenas a mais, enquanto Ground Zero adiciona 14) e 5 fases CTF (embora tenha q ter algumas manhas para fazer esse modo funcionar. Inclui 5 mapas, mas outros 3 foram lançados oficialmente, basta procurar na internet... Além deles, existem alguns outros mapas oficias, incluindo alguns para 64 Jogadores simultaneos, mas n cheguei a procurar muito sobre). O tempo de campanha depende de uma das 4 dificuldades (a dificuldade hard+ só pode ser acessada via Console), durando entre 4 a 10 horas (também depende de vc querer completar 100%, achando os secrets e matando todos os inimigos). As expansões, juntas, demoram um tanto mais... Algo entre 2 a 10 horas cada (Ground Zero + Turrets = Se prepara pra perder tempo).

[b]Jogabilidade[/b] [u]9/10[/u]
O maior erro do Quake original, não poder agachar, foi corrigido aqui. A movimentação do game tbm mudou bastante, agora sendo mais simples que o primeiro jogo, o que os jogadores mais competitivos n gostaram muito. Em geral, jogo é mais lento, já que há muitas escadas (se voce bate em um degrau da escada enquanto corre, você desacelera, diferente de Quake III Arena, que você pode continuar pulando nela para n perder tanta velocidade), vários lugares para se agachar e obstáculos no caminho. Quake II: Ground Zero consegue ser mais lerdo ainda graças à turrets, mas mesmo assim, bem mais rápido q os jogos de FPS modernos. Em relação aos ítens e aos inimigos do jogo, ele tem uma variedade bem grande de ambas, e suas expansões auxiliam nisso, com mais recursos para recolher e ameaças a se enfrentar, sendo bem reguladas no jogo (embora a maioria dos chefes seja fácil matar com a Grande Ferrando Arma :P).

[b]Trilha Sonora[/b] [u]9/10[/u]
É um rock muito bom, mas nem sempre combina com o ambiente. Descent Into Cerberon > All. A versão da Steam está sem música, então procurem o patch!

[b]Gráficos[/b] [u]9/10[/u]
Os gráficos do jogo eram muito bons na época que foi lançado, e na moral, não envelheceram tão mal assim (a n ser que você n goste de marrom claro... 90% do jogo é marrom), diferente de Quake 1, que os modelos e suas animações ficaram meio ruins com o tempo (sorte que existem Source Ports para nos livrar daquelas animações de 5 frames :D). De qualquer maneira, o jogo tinha ótimos gráficos, mesmo comparado aos outros jogos da época.

[b]Otimização[/b] [u]9,5/10[/u]
Vai rodar até na batata, a versão da Steam não tem música, mas com patch da pra arrumar, tirando isso o jogo roda liso. Tem alguns bugs (como pedaços de gibs voando no nada), mas são bem raros.

[b]Level Design[/b] [u]7,5/10[/u]
Então, aqui estamos... Definitivamente, o pior problema do jogo. Lembram quando eu disse que a música deveria mudar quando o jogo tivesse climas mais ambientes? Poisé, o que acontece é que os lugares do jogo são todos muito parecidos visualmente, e fazem com que tenhamos a sensação de estar sempre na mesma fase, fazendo as mesmas coisas com clima frenético mesmo quando o ambiente é de muita escuridão (maldita música), e as cores usadas não ajudaram muito (lembram do marrom? Quake 1 tbm sofreu disso, mas pelo menos o level design era mais interessante), fazendo o jogo ficar meio repetitivo as vezes. Esse jogo não teve a participação de Romero, o que com certeza fez o level design piorar de qualidade nos jogos da ID a partir deste.

[b]Enredo[/b] [u]8,5/10[/u]
Um dos avanços desse jogo em relação aos jogos anteriores da ID foi, sem dúvidas, o enredo. Ele teve uma boa melhorada, tendo falas entre os soldados durante algumas fases. Basicamente todas as missões do jogo tem alguma explicação pela qual devem ser realizadas, o que deixa tudo mais interessante. Uma pena Quake III não ter campanha, pois se tivesse um enredo como o deste jogo, seria muito interessante.

[b]Multiplayer[/b] [u]8/10[/u]
Ok, esse aqui é quase um 8,5. O que acontece aqui é que os servidores são praticamente vazios, raramente você acha alguém para enfrentar neste jogo (mesmo com source port!!!), diferente de Quake 1, que ainda hoje é possível encontrar server no nQuake. Sobre o multiplayer em si, ele não tem nada demais. A jogabilidade lembra mais Quake III do que o primeiro, ele é razoavelmente rápido (mas as escadas ainda são um problema), tem rocket/strafe jump, vem alguns mapas Deathmatch inclusos (as expansões tem até mais mapas que o próprio Quake II, mas boa sorte em achar alguém que jogue nelas :P), etc. Se quiserem Multiplayer, vão de I, III ou Live. É possível jogar a campanha em modo coop.


[b]GERAL[/b] [u]8,5/10[/u]
O jogo é excelente. Podia ter sido melhor? Podia. Mas foi bom? Na minha opinião, sim. Então, tudo depende de você agora :).
