[h1][b]Quake II				* 9/10[/b][/h1]

One of the most badass and scary games I've played in my childhood. Period.

Quake II is a classic FPS, which was famous because at the time it supported 3d Graphic Acceleration (the good old 3dfx), the enemy AI was very improved from the classic "runandshootatyou" (enemies had different kind of attacks and behaviours, and the most dangerous ones will crouch to avoid your projectiles), many of them will still try to shoot you a couple of times before dying and... flies will gather around fresh corpses of enemies you've just killed... XD
At its days this game held a huge amount of innovations and, considering the title, one of them was the completely different setting from the previous chapter. No more dungeon-medieval themed levels and enemies: now there are stroggs, cybernetic aliens that create their army by taking enemies corpses and reviving them with cybernetic improvements. Scary enough? Not until you see the levels with your space marine comrades captured, tortured and gone completely crazy. Definitely on a different level compared to Quake.
The arsenal is more interesting than the previous chapter and even bigger, considering there are 10 weapons, and there's a BFG again.
Another huge innovation is the level structure. It was confusing at the time because in certain areas you had to solve certain puzzles in order to proceed, and they required items or explorations in other "dead end-levels".
As a metalhead I can't help but mention the badass soundtrack, something rare to hear nowadays.
Another interesting thing is the possibility to play in Coop the main campaign.
Long story short, this game is the definition of "Old but Gold".

[h1]+++PROs+++[/h1][list]
[*][b] ENGINE.[/b] The Quake II Engine is quite old now, but it still is enjoyable nowadays.
[*][b] SOUNDTRACK.[/b] Very Badass Soundtrack. 'Nuff said...
[*][b] INNOVATION.[/b] Nowadays it may look quite a common game but for the time this title was so full of innovation from the Enemy AI to the Level structure.
[*][b] SETTING.[/b] The stroggs are quite scary considering their "nature" and the levels we find them in, not to mention the tortured marines we find around in the most advanced levels.
[/list]
[h1]---CONs---[/h1][list]
....... ehm....
[*][b] OLD.[/b] It's old. It's not a DX12 game. Is this a good reason to ignore this game?
[*][b] COMPATIBILITY ISSUES.[/b] OK, seriously, as usual this game presents compatibility issues due to its age. Luckily there's the Steam community with various solutions and patches that will make this game run flawlessly, as if your i7 with your GTX 970 was an MMX with a Vodoo 3dfx... And, seriously, if you want to exploit more your hardware you can always look up for some Port that will load the game for you with enhanced graphics.
[*][b] STEAM RELEASE.[/b] This is supposed to be the classic garbage steam release, with no particular updates and some compatibility issues, as mentioned before. I am told there's not even the music in this release. I never noticed as I HAD to use the patch to make it run and this patch includes music as well. So no particular harm was done to me... Still there are some Old game bugs that I still remember since its original release, such as missing power cubes, unopened doors holding data spinners or loop levels, where you follow the objectives, go to a level, follow your objectives, then it tells to go back and once you're done there's a barrier blocking you, asking you to do everything again (Reactor and Cooling facility)... Meh... Nothing that a good old noclip can't fix... XD
[/list]

23009850.review:
Quake II è uno sparatutto in prima persona (FPS) old style sviluppato da id Software nel 1997.
Dal punto di vista tecnico, il gioco è solidissimo: fluido, rapido, frenetico, con uno shooting perfetto come non se ne vede ai tempi odierni; ottimo il level design, con tantissimi segreti da scoprire, piattaforme e interruttori da attivare; ci sarà un po' di backtracking ma la cosa sarà sempre gradevole in quanto vi saranno sempre tonnellate di nemici. Le armi sono varie e numerose come in un buon fps old style, così come i nemici, anch'essi numerosi e variegati. Da segnalare anche l'ottima velocità di passo, il salto molto fluido, rapido e abbastanza alto e la possibilità (non scontata in fps di quel periodo) di lanciare granate con le mani (e non solo col lanciagranate). Il gioco garantisce sempre un buon livello di scontro e non sarà una passeggiata neppure a normale.
La grafica è naturalmente datata oggi che sono passati quasi vent'anni dalla sua uscita, ma sicuramente mantiene ancora dei modelli abbastanza accattivanti e fluidi; inoltre, la semplicità grafica tipica di Quake si mantiene tutta, permettendo una perfetta fluidità e fruibilità del mondo di gioco e consentendo di distinguere sempre chiaramente i nemici. Rispetto a Doom trovo lo stile di Quake tradizionalmente un po' più "fumettoso" (anche se non lo è), semplicemente perché è caratterizzato da colori più accessi e lucidi, aree di gioco più luminose e ha un impronta più da puro shooting che da horror come gli ultimi Doom. 
Sul sonoro non posso commentare, in questa versione non pare eccezionale, ma a sentire i commenti sembra che sia stato mutilato rispetto all'originale.
Il comparto tecnico funziona bene: frame-rate stabile (soprattutto su computer odierni che non hanno problemi a farlo girare), nessun crash (anche se ho avuto un piccolo blocco in una sezione mentre sparavo a raffica) e l'I.A. sembra abbastanza ordinaria: nulla di eccelso, ma i nemici non saranno dei completi idioti, cercheranno di muoversi per evitare i colpi e soprattutto ci vengono sotto se scappiamo.
Longevità ottima, molto superiore agli standard dei moderni fps.

Gioco finito il 15/09/2016 dopo molto tempo senza giocare: confermato tutto quanto, titolo bellissimo e boss fight ispirate, anche se non difficilissime se si è ben forniti di armi. 
Unico difetto vero, forse, l'eccessiva "labirintosità" dei livelli e l'assenza della colonna sonora (tipica della versione Steam -.-)


Pro:
- Gameplay abbastanza diversificato per l'epoca, movimenti rapidi e shooting fluido
- Nemici variegati e armi numerose
- Buon livello di sfida
- Design accattivante e elaborato con intere aree da scoprire
- Sangue a fiumi

Contro:
- Sonoro non eccelso (ma pare sia un problema della versione Steam)

Voto:
10/10

21170244.review:
A review for this game is long overdue... I'll try to keep it short and sweet.

Quake II is without a doubt one of the greatest FPS games ever created. It was ahead of its time in so many ways when it was released in 1997 and almost 20 years later it's still a great looking game and fun as hell to play. 

This game, along with duke3d, was basically my teenage years (I know, I know, biased review, eh?). Between 1998-2001 I'd say I spent 80% of my gaming time on Quake 2. I was there for the q2_test.exe release, before the deathmatch maps (Q2DM1-8) were released, before player models had viewable weapons (this was created by the modding community), and when [url=http://lmctf.com/]LMCTF[/url] (the original/first CTF game mode also created by the community) was released. Quake 2 was THE game and you couldn't [url=http://www.bluesnews.com/archives/dec97-4.html]escape it;[/url] it was everywhere and for good reason too!

I have yet to find an FPS game today that has such a great single player campaign and amazing multiplayer with some of the best balanced weapons ever. The movement is fluid and fast. The look, feel and sound of the weapons are top notch. No one can touch the Q2 Railgun, it's THE pimp gun to use and FEELS powerful as it should. 

Where the game really shines though is in the maps. I cannot stress enough how amazing and memorable the level design in Quake 2 is. Every single map is a work of art. At the time I craved city style maps and environments like the ones found in Duke Nukem 3D but now the tables have turned; those kind of environments are practically in every FPS currently being released and I long for the sci-fi and gothic based fantasy worlds of Quake. 

As I'm writing this review I searched online to find out just who exactly is responsible for creating these amazing maps. I almost gave up until I found one of John Romero's archived .plan files. Apparently Tim Willits created the bulk of the maps in Quake 2. Romero himself praised the level design by saying [quote="John Romero"] I'm a map designer at heart and the levels in Quake 2 are the most beautifully architected alternate realities i've ever experienced. They are so much better than Quake 1's maps that i'm almost embarassed to see my earlier work and say that it's still good.[/quote]  So I'm not alone or crazy when I worship these maps :) If you're interested in reading Romero's full thoughts on Quake 2 scroll down to [url=http://dk.toastednet.org/dotPlan/romeroplan_1997.htm]December 11, 1997[/url]

I believe this is the game developers should study when aiming to make an old school type of shooter today. Primarily for the level design/layout but also for enemy placement because hordes of enemies coming at you in waves gets boring very fast. 

Out of all the Quake games I think this is the best looking one to date. The atmosphere in it is just awesome especially with all the environmental sounds masterfully placed throughout the game. 

If you're a fan of the FPS genre you need to play this game. Forget Half Life, this was the game that took the world by storm. This game is a masterpiece. 

I would recommend playing Quake 2 as vanilla as possible. For that I would HIGHLY recommend using the Yamagi source port which supports in-game music through .OGG file format so you can listen to the soundtrack (since Steam doesn't provide it) while playing as intended. All sorts of custom resolutions are supported but the best thing about the Yamagi source port is their GL renderer which displays Quake 2's colours beautifully and authentic just like in 1997. 
It also has an active development on [url=https://github.com/yquake2] Github[/url] and over 1000 bugs fixed, making Yamagi one of the most bug free Quake 2 ports available.

You can use the patch below to install Yamagi with the soundtrack instantly.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1223177211


The community and multiplayer is very much alive.
A big thank you to quadz and whoever else is responsible for running [url=http://www.tastyspleen.net/]Tastyspleen[/url] -- This is basically the bulk of Q2 community.

Story
An evil alien race called the Strogg had invaded Earth but Earth managed to push them and are going to do a counter-attack. Now humanity must destroy the Strogg defences and assassinated their leader. The story is simple but it's a shooter from the 90s so of course but the Strogg are a truly vile race. They're one of those races that turn other races into their own and the destroyed their ecosystem for their war machine. They're one of those races no would miss.

Gameplay
Like Hexen, Quake 2's levels are part of a hub system were you have to do missions to get through each section. It also has an inventory which I don't use that much and I really like the guns in this, my personal favorite, the shotgun is still useful for any situation, the railgun is a great sniper rifle, the rocket launcher is great for big or far away enemies, the grenade launcher is useful for corners and the BFG. Though I had less use for the Hyper Blaster as the Chaingun was more powerful in my opinion. Even the starter blaster is useful for guards and enemies that can't shoot you.
But that's the regular game, lets talk about the mission packs. While both of them have new items I never used because I don't know what they do. The new weapons didn't look or feel that great or powerful and I forgot I had them and for the new enemies, while Ground Zero has some good upgraded enemies and some good bosses, The Reckoning is disappointing in that regard. While I like the gex and the brains needed that upgrade, but the new guards really got on my nerves and the other new enemies were either new weapons I didn't notice or just buff up the health of them. I'm looking at you Tank Beta.

Presentation
Steam version doesn't have music but I do have the soundtrack and it's okay. There are a few tracks I really like March of the Strogg and Climb and the music fit the strogg as a race. While it doesn't have a big colour palette, the locations do look distict like the warehouse looks a warehouse, the mines look like mines, power plant looks like a power plant. The Stroog themselves also look cool, the mix of flesh and metal, and each one looks more dangerous than the last. and like all good enemy design, you tell who's who just be looking or hearing them.

Verdict
while Quake 2 is a solid game on it's own, if you want you can get the mission packs for some more action.
Quake 2: 8/10
Mission packs 7/10

20481251.review:
I feel like an outcast when I say this at times. But I don't like the singleplayer to Quake 2.

The original Quake is one of my favorite first person shooters ever. It features a great sense of speed and flow. Levels are completed relatively quickly, the enemies were very original and forced the player to adapt to the levels, and the game had this spooky haunted house aesthetic combined with an excellent OST by Nine Inch Nails.

Quake 2 however always felt to me like a step backwards. A lot of the enemies are much more generic cyborgs with hitscan weapons that mostly just stand as obstacles before you get a keycard to open a door. There's no sense of flow to the levels where you're expected to prioritize enemies by how dangerous they were and how much they required you to dodge their attacks. Here I just go into a room, shoot 3 similar enemies standing still, repeat. It makes the game feel very dull and for many years I never understood why I could never finish Quake 2 until I started to notice that.

However all that being said the biggest thing Quake 2 does well is it's multiplayer. Quake 2's multiplayer in many ways is a lot better than the original. It features great diversity with weapons like rocket launchers and railguns. Complete with a great selection of levels. The high octane heavy metal soundtrack Quake 2 has suits a multiplayer game much more than Quake 1's spooky haunted house music did.

It's one of my more polarizing opinions on the game. I don't really hate Quake 2 since there are things about it I like. But it's easily the Id singleplayer game I've played the least of.

[b]Quake[/b]. Это слово знакомо каждому человеку, связавшему свои развлечения с видеоиграми. Создатели [b]Quake[/b] — [i]id Software[/i], в период своего расцвета, придумали как минимум две, наиболее узнаваемые во всем мире, серии игр. Это, конечно же, [b]DOOM[/b] и [b]Quake[/b].
[b]DOOM[/b] (вместе с [b]Wolfenstein 3D[/b]) подарили нам жанр «шутер», а [b]Quake[/b] определил основные черты и признаки нового, на тот момент, жанра. [i]id Software[/i] стали, своего рода, первопроходцами на заре миллениума.

Но ведь могли бы и промахнуться, всё же ни для кого не секрет, что первый [b]Quake[/b] изначально задумывался как игра в наиболее популярном, на тот момент, жанре [i]RPG[/i]. Остатки этой затеи остались в игре в виде некоторого оружия, внешнего вида уровней и врагов.
Именно поэтому многие предпочитают [b]Quake II[/b], потому как только ко второй части игра вобрала в себя весь колорит присущий серии. В игре появились индустриальные пейзажи, работающие механизмы, строгги, их символика и общий узнаваемый стиль. В игру внедрили хоть и очень скудный, но сюжет, ролики и примерную цель для всех этих похождений.
Из-за всего этого [b]Quake II[/b] не является прямым продолжением первой части, поэтому сравнивать эти игры не очень корректно, но не делать этого тоже нельзя, так как их объединяет слишком многое. Как минимум разработчик, название и технологии.

Движок [b]id Tech 2[/b], написанный Джоном Кармаком, и по сей день остаётся одним из лидеров пр количеству игр разработанных на нем. Шутка ли, но без [b]Quake II[/b] и [b]id Tech 2[/b] мир не увидел бы великого и ужасного [b]Half-Life[/b], а если бы это всё-таки произошло, то это была бы совершенно другая игра. Чувствуете увесистость и влияние?

Сетевые сражения были и до [b]Quake II[/b], но благодаря детищу [i]id Software[/i] они получили качественное развитие в динамике и балансе. В начале нулевых, до выхода [b]Counter-Strike[/b] и [b]Quake III Arena[/b], было действительно сложно найти компьютерный клуб, где не гоняли бы в [b]Quake II[/b]. А некоторые, самые преданные фанаты, делают это и по сей день. Благо игра и её сетевой протокол до сих пор работают как часы, даже на современных системах.

Как ни крути, но [b]Quake II[/b] — это культ, веха и столп, сродни некоторым другим громким проектам этой студии. Пройдёт еще много лет, на свет появятся кучи игр, хороших и не очень, снова сменятся поколения игроков, но в детища [i]id Software[/i] будут играть, переигрывать и вспоминать как это было в конце девяностых.

Если уж компьютерные развлечения считать искусством, то и среди игр должны быть свои шедевры и редкие самородки. [b]Quake II[/b] один из таких шедевров, который пройдет сквозь время и уже вряд ли когда-то забудется.

P.S. И помните — рельса не имеет ничего общего с железными дорогами.

20023739.review:
The First Person SHooter is on of the youngest innovations and new gameplay genres being about 20 years old. It gave some gamers exactly what they wanted from an action relentless fast paced in your face action. ID software set out to change the world with Wolfenstein 3-D and then changed the world for a second time with the original DOOM in 1993. Doom and Wolfenstein brought to the table staples of the genre back in the day:
1. Key hunts
2. Lots of Action
3.Progressivley Harder enemies
4.Secrets
5.Limited health and ammo
6.And your basic loadout of guns
Doom improved upon these with its very open very maze like levels, lots and lots of gore, a crapton more enemies(and a larger variety of them at that) the list goes on and on. But they made one last change to the whole FPS genre that changed what people that the capcity of a shooter was. One word, one single word that shook the gaming world forever. It stoodm for something that would leave other shooters in the dust: "QUAKE". This was the first truly 3-D shooter where the graphics did'nt look like crap. The models and textures were great for the time, each episode had totally different and unique art styles, enemies, and textures. The game had fast paced action and what seemed like fucking neverending waves of enemies. Now that's all fine and good but what really made QUAKE huge: ONLINE MULTIPLAYER. It was there in DOOM but QUAKE made it better.

Now what do I think of Quake 2.........HOLY BALLS THIS GAMES KICKS MORE ASS THEN A DONKEY ABUSER.
Quake 2 had wayyy ahead of it's time graphics back in the day, better multiplayer, smoother and faster gameplay, but it had one thing that even today is still used in every single FPS today and that is a mission structure for every single level. Instead of just finding keys, killing enemies then ending the level. You are now told why you are doing this via a computer menu (can be opened by pressing F1 by default) this gave  some sort of structure to the game that wasn't too offensive. The levels are still fairly open and explorable with some areas not being open until you beat a later level. That's another thing as the game progresses there will be times where you have to return too return to a previously explred area to continue which I found cool. 

The music absolutley steals the show with this one. Doom had an excellent thrash metal soundtrack that kicked ass and made you wanna rip and tear through all kinds of alien zombie bastards but Quake 2 IMO completley blows it out of the water. With a very head-banging heavy metal soundtrack (that sounds all kinds of crisp because CD based music and shiz) it feels like the perfect soundtrack for a game about a lone marine killing everything that breathes in his general directoin. The soundtrack is what made me pursue this game and is part of the reason why I think this game has aged fairly well.

Overall quake 2 is kick fucking ass. Great visuals, good enemy variety, AMAZING MUSIC, cool guns, addictive multiplayer, frantic and fast paaced action that keeps you on your toes, and classic key card hunts make this an FPS everyone absolutley has to try. Its not perfect and the visuals have aged but the fast action, high difficulty and great music keeps this game alive and kicking.

I LOVE THIS GAME AND SO SHOULD YOU FPS FANS

19977068.review:
Quake deslumbró en su lanzamiento siendo una nueva obra maestra por parte de ID Software, subiendo el listón tecnológico que supuso Doom, y apostando por recrear un escenario más barroco y lúgubre que su obra cumbre. Lejos de lo que esperarían en su día los seguidores de la recién nacida obra de ID Software, su secuela no iba a apostar por el mismo escenario, y de hecho en cierto modo iba a estar más cercano a Doom que al primer Quake en algunos aspectos, pero también fue un capítulo determinante para introducir nuevas ideas que ya empezaban a asomar en juegos de la época.

Quake II nos pone en la piel de un soldado humano en mitad de un asalto a un planeta habitado por unos seres llamados "Stroggs", alienígenas cyborgs, mitad orgánicos, mitad máquina. Tendremos que movernos por las numerosas instalaciones que resguardan los sistemas de defensas de los Stroggs, y otros secretos que iremos conociendo de esta infame especie hasta llegar al Makron, el lider de los Stroggs que comanda el ataque contra los humanos.

La premisa es sencilla, el argumento queda en segundo plano, pero a diferencia de otros juegos anteriores de ID Software, Quake II introdujo objetivos y misiones a cumplir durante nuestro enfrentamiento con los Stroggs, lo que hacía que ya no se tratara solo de avanzar y disparar hasta el final de fase, aunque el concepto de abrir puertas con llaves, encontrar objetos  y demás no era algo desconocido. El gunplay se siente incluso hoy en día excelente, ágil y excitante, cargado de acción y con las armas necesarias para encarar los distintos enfrentamientos contra los Stroggs, numerosas clases de enemigos durante más de 35 fases a lo largo del juego. Algo que brillaba con fuerza y que hoy en día sigue siendo apreciable a la vista de que muchos shooters han decidido tirar por desarrollos más lineales, es la estructura y arquitectura de niveles, como era tradicional en ID Software, resultaban retorcidos y repletos de obstáculos y secretos, sin llegar al nivel de desesperar.

No tiene mucho sentido hablar de su calidad gráfica casi 20 años después, pero en su día fue un bombazo, como era costumbre de su desarrolladora, y aunque hoy en día la versión de Steam no lo incluye de serie, la banda sonora, una suerte de rock y metal industrial firmado por Sonic Mayhem, era un complemento excelente ante la acción que descargaba este nuevo Quake (aún se puede implementar en el juego con su correspondiente parche), menos atmosférico y lúgubre que su antecesor, pero más vibrante y dinámico si cabe. El multiplayer tampoco lo he probado hoy en día, pero en su día fue todo en referente.

En conclusión, Quake II es en pleno 2015/2016 una pieza de historia y de nostalgia para los que vivieron su época. Una época que a diferencia de lo que solemos encontrar hoy, era muy distinto cuando hablábamos de ports y otras versiones. PC era la plataforma nativa de Quake, y las versiones de consolas de su época (PSX y N64) estuvieron recortadas o incluso totalmente modificadas no solo en el plano técnico, sino en el número de fases o en el diseño de estas. La versión de Quake II de PC y que podemos encontrar hoy, es la edición más completa y la que vio la luz originalmente. Tanto si eres un nostálgico, como un aventurero de los clásicos o simplemente un yonki de la acción y la adrenalina  que proporcionan los FPS "old-school", Quake II sigue siendo un videojuego enormemente recomendable.

В очередной раз запустив Q, я словно потерялся во времени. Все как в былые времена: потерпевшая падение капсула, бластер, и беспощадная мясорубка строггатины. А так же поиск секретов; нежданчиков на скорости за двести (и под кваддамагом) и конечно, великолепные пейзажи под уже, наверное классику индастриал металла отличного композитора "Sonic Mayhem"!

[h1]id tech II[/h1]
Прошло чуть более года, а из под молотов команды Джона Кармака вылетела новая веха во вселенной Quake. И оглянувшись на предшественника, ты наверняка спросишь: —Почему Quake? Ведь между играми схожего не так уж и много. Геймплей, "H-ha!"*, да пушки, и то частично... Как гласит история, id не особо раздумывали над подходящим заголовком. Да и оглядываясь на другого монстра — Doom, оба названия имеют некую аллегорию. Да и зачем игре какое-то имя, когда на экране творится безбашенный геймплей? Конечно, как ты корабль назовешь, так он и поплывет. Кармак же именовал ракету.

[h1]Прогулки по "Stroggos"[/h1]
К слову о движке. В наше время, в эпоху ценителей графона, большой разницы в картинке между первой и второй и не уловишь. Все главные вкусности под капотом. Детализация обросла чуть большим кол-вом полигонов. Сам движок обзавелся новыми фишками. Сетевой код был улучшен со времен первой Q. Освещение стало насыщенней и разнообразней. Но все-равно это тот же самый квейк! Ни капли изменений в геймплее. А вот уровни - это просто фантастика! Большие, иногда запутанные (но не Wolfenstein), разнообразные и несущие в себе определенный смысл, передающие атмосферу накаленной обстановки в самой гуще на вражеской планете "Stroggos".

[h1]"March of the Stroggs"[/h1]
Враги стали разнообразней. Каждый класс по-своему уникален и имеет индивидуальные фишки боя. ИИ поумнел. Теперь игра может удивить игрока, заставив строггов биться между друг другом. Можно сагрить противников, и они станут до победного "выяснять отношения"**.
Арсенал так же стал внушительнее. Из ярких особенностей в пример автомат, имитирующий отдачу при стрельбе. Что в свою очередь придает немного реалистичности с точки зрения поведения оружия. Или, уже культовый Рейлган. Пробивает в линию сразу нескольких строггов! Еще одна интересная фишка - энергетическая броня. Процент ее прочности зависит от кол-ва боезапаса Гипербластера, и пропорционален силе атаки противника.

[h1]ПРО сеть.[/h1]
Вспоминаются школьные года... Урок английского, пацаны шпилят кваку в кабинете информатики. Информатика: —Да как?! Откуда прилетело? Даже сам учитель информатики составлял нам компанию, на уроке информатики :D
Что можно добавить к тому, что мультиплеер кваки — это целый культ воспоминаний? Это компьютерные клубы. Игра по модему и сети на q2dm1. И по сей день. Разве что в кооперативе кваку не играл.

[h1]P.S.[/h1]
Quake II  - классика старой школы. Q - это тысячи переигранных раз, и каждый раз, словно амнезия. Да черт возьми, квака — это повод для добрых и веселых, ламповых воспоминаний из прошлого, наверное каждого. Для игры вышло два официальных дополнения. Но о них в соответствующем месте, и когда придет время...
Конечно, сейчас в "голый" оригинал навряд-ли поспидраниш... спасибо Джону Кармаку за открытый код, и тем создателям модов, позволивших продолжать комфортно играть в этот ураганный нон-стоп шутан! И спасибо тебе, читатель, коли ты осилил эту гору букв...

19901021.review:
As someone who was born too early to enjoy the '90s first-person shooter craze, series like Doom and Quake were something that passed over me.  Arena shooters (Painkiller, Serious Sam, etc.) were what started my old-school fascination.

While both Doom's and Quake's games are timeless, I find that the Quake series is something more familiar for newcomers than the original Doom games. 3D level design of Quake is hardly something new compared to the sprite-based 2.5D design of Doom.

Even with programs to enable mouselook and higher textures/better effects for Doom, the Quake series feels like a game that has only aged by its looks. Not the core gameplay.

[h1]Audio Problems: Get Ultimate Quake Patch[/h1]

For some technical reason, Steam's version of Quake (and Quake 2) do not have the soundtracks included. Before you go to GOG, you should know that their version also lacks the soundtracks. 

If you type in Ultimate Quake Patch (for one or two), you'll find Steam pages where you can download a specific patch just for Steam which will run the game on some other engine with the soundtrack fixed as well as larger font for messages. (It also has controller/joypad support).

I cannot stress this enough: You need that patch. Playing this game without the soundtrack is so boring. Admittedly it feels more atmospherc and horrorish, but having the soundtrack will ease your nerves and keep you going. (The texts also seem more abundant to let you know what to do next.)

[h1]Why You Should Play Quake (and Quake 2) in 2015[/h1]

The main reason I think Quake is much easier to get into than Doom is not the visuals nor the lack of freelook (without any mods or programs like GZDoom, obviously). No, the main reason is because of Quake's sense of verticality and the 3D level design.

The level design of Quake games are these open-ended, yet linear, maps where objectives require you to move from one place to the next. These involve different transitions to new areas or multiple floor areas with secrets hidden plenty. And backtracking rewards you with finding secrets or alternative routes through the levels.

It's also important to note that these games being linear is not a bad thing. In fact, it's how the game obscures its linear nature that makes it feel rewarding. 

The 3D level design makes the game never feel like an 2D labyrinth where you have to exhaust all means to find the exit, and the ways the levels twist-back on themselves makes the levels have a nice sense of cohesion and thought put into them. 

That attention is made clear with Quake's sense of verticality. It's not just having multiple floors; Doom has several levels with elevation changes. The game relies on the one thing that breaks Doom: Jumping.

Even if you enable mouse-look for Doom to make it play like a modern game, enabling the ability to jump will break the game itself. Secrets, manueverability around enemies, etc. were built around that limitation, and it feels like an artificial limitation to not use the jump button yourself.

Quake, however, rewards exploration with the mechanic. It enables you a viable means to fake-out the enemies or dodge a projectile. It encourages you to explore above you and below for items you may need. 

All of what I'm saying is Quake's demand of the player's spatial awareness goes a long way to distract the player from what is otherwise a linear experience.

[h1]Forget the Numbers[/h1]

The differences between Q1 and Q2 are too numerous to state here. They play similarly enough, yet they both look and feel far removed from each other that you could consider them two seperate games. I think it's personal preference for which is superior.

However, there are several things about Q2 that I think would make it a better introduction than the first game.

For starters, the enemy abilities and telegraphs are much more obvious than in Q1. While I love the Lovecraftian/Gothic Horror vibe of Q1, the Strogg are simply a better enemy type because they all stand out and they all have better visual cues for the player.

Compare the Strogg with the chaingun and grenade launcher hands from Q2 to the chainsaw guys in Q1. It is much clearer to know what to do when the arm with the grenade launcher aims at you than the chainsaw guy's other arm. 

A lot of enemies in Q2 have visual cues that you'll learn without having your hand held by the game. The enemies' designs are varied to not become confusing when you have to handle more than one.

Another reason why Q2 is a better place to start is that the game isn't relentless with its enemy mobs. Q1 is more relentless with its nonstop action; Q2 relies on pacing out the fights to guide the player in the "right" direction. 

There are also gameplay means to ease the difficulty. Things like the Power Armor (charged by cells for some guns) will improve your odds at the cost of not using up your more powerful weapons.  (And then you have the power-ups you can ration out.)

These will encourage you to not save-scum your way through the game, which will help you get better at other old-school games (like Quake 1).

[h1]"Where do I go? What do I do?"[/h1]

Backtracking is one thing about Quake 2 that may make or break you, and unlike Doom there is no map-screen.

The game is full of backtracking objectives, but you will more often know where the next objective is if you're thorough with your exploration.

For the most part.

While I have gone into great detail for how Quake relies on the player's awareness for their surroundings, I found one part of the game impossible to solve on my own for my first and second playthrough: Mission 9. 

Normally, you can usually check your Mission Objectives to nudge you into the right area to be, and there is usually some visual clue on what you affected with a switch or button. (Besides the text prompts or map names.) And the levels usually feature some visually themed objects or names of facilities to let you know what you are walking into.

Even with a year's difference between my first and second playthrough, I found most of the direction of Q2 intutive and not time-consuming. Except for Mission 9: the Inner and Outer Palace. 

This level is an absolute mess of switching forcefields off, transitioning between loading screens, and other means of backtracking. Some rooms feel like Escher staircases, and some rooms will take you to areas you didn't think would be there.

Solution for mission 9: Bring an FAQ or find a video guide to help.

[h1]An Unoriginal Classic[/h1]

Though not as groundbreaking or "new" as DOOM and not as favorited as the original, Quake 2 is still a well-polished game despite the aging years. Brown-grime color palatte and the lacking Gothic Horror tone aside, Q2 is a classic old-school first-person-shooter that deserves to be played by modern audiences.

It's a game that has not aged well on the eyes, yet it has retained all its vigor in its design.

19800726.review:
Ah, Quake II. I remember the first time I played this wonderful game. It was a quiet spring day and I got home from school. I immediately booted up my old Windows 98, which was a little slow but for games it worked well. I waited patiently for it to finish loading up everything. While it was doing that, I looked around the messy computer desk to find a game to play when I found a copy of a game with a name that I immediately recognized. Quake II. I had already played the first game. It was one of the first games I ever played. It was a memory that would never leave my head. So, as a curious child with nothing else to do, I popped the game into my CD drive.

I immediately noticed something different with the game. The install screen showed creatures I had never seen from the first game and the backgrounds during installation showed futuristic facilities that looked nothing like the first game. I was confused, but excited at the same time. I could not wait to see what hid inside the game itself. The game finished installing and, as a now very excited child, started up the game. The menus looked and sounded a lot different from the near-steampunk menus of the first game, but I shrugged, set the difficulty on easy (I was a kid what do you expect?), and watched the intro.

The intro starts off with a camera zooming out of a weird structure while weird news reports were discussing the plot of the game. An alien race, known as the Strogg, have invaded earth in a galactic war against the human race. They destroyed numerous cities in their time on Earth. The humans surprisingly shove them back home and now we are going to fight them on the Strogg home planet. Then the camera zoomed out to the Quake II logo. A light suddenly shined behind it and blew up the logo! I was completely speechless. I didn't know what else to do except keep watching.

After the explosion, a ship flies from the bottom of the screen with tons of guns and artillery for taking the Strogg down. The intro then cuts to a bay that looked like a prison, but then the doors opened and revealed what I thought initially were cannons. Next I saw one of these weird things about to be launched. It had the name "Bitterman" on it. I then knew that these were pods about to be sent to take down the Strogg. After being launched, Bitterman gets clipped by some cowboy and loses a little control but gets situated. On the planet, we come to this big cannon looking thing on the planet and suddenly...all hell breaks loose.

Screams blast through my speakers as I learn what happens next. Apparently, the Strogg forces knew the humans would be coming, so they prepared an EMP for them and killed the marines with it. Somehow, getting clipped by that cowboy saves Bitterman, but he overshoots the landing zone and crash lands into a bunker on the left side of the big gun. The screen goes black as the sound of clashing steel fills my speakers. Shocked by the intro I had just witnessed, I had to play this game. I was completely speechless from the intro and I had to see what the gameplay was like.

As soon as the game started up, I looked at where I was and was amazed by the graphics. It looked great! And I loved how I could see the hand that was holding the gun. A nice touch by id Software, and a really innovative thing for 3D graphics in 1998. The look of the levels was really astonishing too! The color looked so much better than the really brown color of the original Quake. I was very pleased with the look of the game.

But when the game loaded, something else filled my speakers. The soundtrack. The legendary guitar-filled soundtrack. This is easily one of the best parts of Quake II. The original Quake had a more ambient soundtrack which did sound great, but I felt that it didn't fit the actions you were doing. Quake II however had a much more fitting soundtrack. It's definitely awesome to listen to. I highly recommend the soundtrack. The sound effects sound really good too. The blaster sounds like I would imagine a blaster to sound like, and the other guns have really satisfying sounds. My favorite sound effect has to be the Super Shotgun blast. It sounds powerful, like how a double-barrel instrument of destruction should sound.

The controls are of course fluent as they should be. One thing Quake II adds is the ability to crouch. It's a nice new action that does help with aiming and avoiding enemy projectiles. It also adds new ways to get secrets in each of the levels that are in the game. Speaking of the levels, I LOVE the level design in Quake II. They are big and wide open with lots of secrets to find. You could play a level for hours just to find all of the secrets! Yes you could do this in the original, but Quake II I feel is a little better at this.

The one thing I did enjoy more than the already awesome single player was the addicting multiplayer. This was the first game I ever played online. I was a child, but that didn't matter to me! I was playing one of my favorite games with other people! I was enjoying all of it! Of course I sucked, but it was fun just playing with others on the internet! It didn't matter to me back then. I was just having fun!

Of course I could only have so much fun with Deathmatch. I did notice however that there was a server with a bunch of players, so I checked it out. I was in for a ride though as I found myself playing what would become my favorite game type in any video game. Good ol' CTF! In CTF, short for Capture The Flag, you are on a team going after the other team's flag and returning it to your base. It was super addicting and really fun. I must have been on for hours just playing CTF with whoever was on at the time! It comes with Quake II nowadays so it's awesome to see that it is avaliable at anytime!

What I also discovered on the CTF server I was on was custom character models to play as in Quake II! Pretty much, a character model, a huge improvement over the skins system in Quakeworld, is a custom-made model of any character you can think of to be used in Quake II to play as. I'm not even joking when I say any character you can think of. There's a huge variety! Beavis and Butthead, the kids from South Park, Fox McCloud, and tons more to choose from! If there's a character, there's probably someone who made them avaliable to play as in Quake II.

Overall, Quake II is legendary. As soon as I was done playing it for the first time, I knew I had found something special. Everything in Quake II is amazing. The graphics, the sound, the single player and multiplayer, everything. It was the first game I tried to introduce to a friend and he got into it really quickly. It was my favorite PC game for many years. If it wasn't for the badass Duke Nukem 3D, this would still be my all-time favorite PC game.

BUY IT NOW!!!!

Habár Quake 2 névre hallgat, az első részhez semmi köze sincs történetileg, és ezt egyébként sokan zokon is vették. A legenda szerint azért kapta ugyanazt a nevet, mert nem kellett egy új címet lekopirájtolni. Node mi a rákról is szól:

A játékban egy Bitterman névre keresztelt űrkatonát alakítunk. A történet a nullához konvergál, és igazából nem derül ki miért is rontunk rá ezekre a csúnya lényekre. Lényeg, hogy a strogg nép mint olyan, jó szokás szerint minden időközönként szépen megy és leigáz egy bolygót. Ilyenkor átveszik a technológiáukat, és az élőlényeiket átalakítják saját kényük kedvük szerint egy cyborggá, és lényegében így építik fel sergeüket. Viszont rossz lóra tettek, amikor sáros bolygónkat célozták meg. Annyira rossz lóra, hogy itt már egy ellencsapásban vehetünk részt, ahol egy strogg bázist támadunk meg.

A run n gun élmény itt is megvan hasonszőrűen az első részhez. Ami mozog annak meg kell hallni. Találkozunk agymosott társainkkal is, akik be vannak zárva cellákba, még őket is megölhetjük ammoért...végülis miért ne. Az enemik úgy átalában nagyon robosztus kiborg katonák, legtöbbször gépágyúval és raksival felszerelkezve. Relatíve sokféle van belőlük, így a végén már elég óriási pédányokkal kell megküzdenünk. Itt megemlíteném, hogy ahol q1-ben a quadot felveszi az ember egyből használnia kell, így kapott a játék egy inventorit. Ennek az a sajátossága, hogy a quadot elhasználhatjuk nagy kan enemire is később. Kicsit szabadabb emiatt az ellenfelek elhelyezése.

A fegyverek talán kevésbé kreatívak. Ami mint új dolog, az a railgun. Konkrétan 100 hp-t vesz le, viszonlag lassabb, de pontos távolról is. Ezen kívűl nagyjából ismerős lesz a fegyverek tárháza q1-ből. Érdekességük, hogy itt már jobban beleillik minden a világba, nem tűnt olyan randomnak az egész mint az első részben. Passzol a szürkés barnás Mars bolygó szerű felszín a hightech strogghoz, és a hightech fegyverarzenálhoz. Legfőképpen azért, mert ezeket a fegyvereket használják majd ellenünk. Még esetleg megemlíthető a színvilág, amit nagyon sokan felhoznak negatívumként: igen, a játék színskálája kimerül a legtöbb esetben a szarbarna és a rozsdabarna kombinációjában. Inkább csak a két kiegészítőre jelelmző a színek és fények jobb használata. Végeredményben nem csúnya tőle a játék, de jelentős visszaesés. Ha belegondoltok, egy mai modern warfare jellegű shooterben is barna tejködben úszik a játék a buta közelkeleti mapokon. Nekem hiányoznak a színek onnan is.

A pályákról megemlíteném, hogy sok az összevissza szaladgálás: kapd fel az akármi magot x mapon, majd menj vissza y mapra berakni a lukba. Aki nem olvassa a pda-t, konkrétan fingja se lesz mit kell hova merre. Én anno konkrétan nem is tudtam, hogy van benne pda. Főleg emiatt el is akadtam benne kismedve koromban. Node sebaj, hiszen most kitoltam fullhdban.

A fullhd felbontást nem annyira egyszerű előcsikarni a játékból steamen. Éppen elfut a játék, még éppen ki tudunk belőle csikarni egy fullhd felbontást (talán többet is), de elég borzasztóan néz ki. Betudható ez főleg annak, hogy időszámításunk előtti opengl rendert használ, legunkább voodoora optimalizálva. Jó hír viszont, hogy az id software általában kiadja a játékok forrás kódját, szóval készültek jó kis kliensek. Habár van kismillió kliens, single playerhez csak a Yamagi klienst tudom ajánlani: felbontás állítás, intro és zene támogatás, mentés támogatás, méretezhető hud. Ezzel végig lehet tolni hagyományos kinézettel és feelinggel.
Ha valaki esetleg többet akar, esetleg bloomot meg nagyobb textúrákat, akkor ott a q2max vagy berserker kliens. Utóbbi nagyon jól néz ki, viszont iszonyat eszi a gépet olykor, és bevallom egyes részek teljesen máshogy néznek ki mint alapjában véve.

A zene ilyen industrial-os metálszerűség. Szintén nagyon jól klappol a játékhoz...és "szintén" csösztek belerakni a digitális verzióba. Ezt orvosolandó tessék menni és leszedni soundtracket a guide részből. Még az is lehet, én is rakok össze egy guideot.

Mindösszességében nem olyan jó mint az első rész...de akárhogyis nézzük van benne railgun, szóval kevesebbet nem adhatok neki 9/10-nél.

Quake II triumphs in many ways compared to it's original predecessor, Quake, or as of nowadays "Quake 1" because that's what happens when a game series shits out sequels like how a housewife in Victorian London shits out children.

However, the story is completely seperate from Quake Juan (implying Quake Won had any story whatsoever) being set on an alien planet where you're some burly white dude going to kill the aliens and their boss because "they're dicks".  The intro cutscene has that whole mid-late 90's animation feel to it, which seems quite nostalgic for me for some reason.

The graphics have improved nicely - I mean I suppose if I don't have to go have my eyes checked after playing a game, I think I can safely say its graphics are acceptable.

The soundtrack is... mostly forgettable.  There is only one piece of soundtrack that stuck out to me and that was 'Descent into Cerberon'.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ALBKFB28E0M

Gameplay, especialy the gunplay, feels a lot more satisfying and much more smooth, although it still sounds like your character has had something shoved up his anal cavities every time he jumps.  However, it falls into the same problem Quake-Wan Kenobi had in term of enemy variety in the sense that you end up having to shoot the same armored guy in the corridor over and over and over again for the good of 5 hours.

The level design is unfortunately pretty maze-like, after you wander around the same corridors for over 10 minutes, you often find yourself wanting something different to show up, at the very least something to shoot at.  I ended up having to look at a walkthrough and the guide told me, at the point I was stuck on and I never like doing this, it doesn't feel like I got the full experience from wandering around the Alien's depiction of a Nazi gas chamber aimlessly until succuming to my own insanity, pulling the trigger of the shotgun resting it's beady little eye on under my chin.

So basically, that was my experience with Quake II, however unless you're a Caveman and live under a rock and/or are living in Iraq then you'll have to download a patch off the internet to make sure the game works properly on your PC!  The cavemen and Tusken Raiders don't have to because they're still using their prehistoric 90's PC to get the full experience and you're not. 

And just for you, being the benevolent Yoshi that I am, I will give you a link to where you can download the patch, because you're worth it. :D http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?p=20806550.

Overall, 6/10.  Fuck the mazes.

17294745.review:
Quake 2 is FPS developed by id and released in 1997 for PC, on their new id Tech 2 engine. It's not really a sequel to Quake 1, but instead it was developed as serapate title and then at the end was given such name. It also had PS1 and N64 ports. I didn't play them, but they are probably inferior ones. Though, from what I seen, PS1 has best usage of colors.

So, how Steam version was handled? In id style! Which means no soundtrack for you. It just wasn't included, once again. You will have to track down (soundtrack) CD of a game. And then deal with music looping issues. _inmm software helped me here.

Game also doesn't support widescreen by default. But I am sure you can find a way to tweak it. Or just use sourceport.
It also was stuttering for me by default. Strange enough, once I would go into Video setting and exit, it would get fixed for me.
It also refused to save configuration for me, so I had to change things back on each launch.

Multiplayer community is small but still there. Now, I may not be good enough to tell away bot from human, but I belive that you will at least find one Deathmatch with 5-10 players. Though yea, Free For All Deathmatch is the only gametype you will end up playing. Small.

The plot follows Bitterman as he is one of the marines that were sent to planet of flesh-hungry cyborgs - Stroggs. As offense is the best defence. He ends up being possibly the only one surviving the first human attack on planet and now has to destroy and disable all the important strogg structures, alone.
So yea, sounds like another Rambo vs World. Though, you can actually meet some captured marines in the levels, but they all went insane. It addsa  nice touch to the setting, though it still feels a bit too gamey to see that you can't interact with them in any way. Or just that there are no sane ones, just crawling around.
It also has CGI cutscenes. Which would be awesome, but it's a wasted potential, as almost all of them are nothing but a fancy intermission screens. Hexen on PS1 made better use of them, really.
Manual is nice though.

And well, to be honest, Quake 2 is the last title in Quake series that I played. I heard that it was a classic and heard many other good things. And once I got to play it, I was amazed... at how awfully generic FPS title it was.

I mean, sure, it's better than Quake on theory. Because more realistical levels. Or better enemy AI. Or just better engine from technical standpoint, with smooth animation and colored lighting.
Yet the game as a whole it creates a fairly dull single-player experience.

Setting isn't exactly interesting. It's nice that levels are connected into small hub and that they are bigger. And that you are given missions that explain what to do next. But level layouts are still linear, so it hardly matters. There are very few interesting levels, mostly factory and research labs, where you can see what Stroggs do with humans. Terrifying.

But outside of them they don't have anything interesting going on, while also not being as abstract as Quake or Doom ones. It also doesn't help that game looks awful. Whatever technical improvements engine may have, they all are supposed to just improve art design. And art design here is quite bad, consisting of red and grey. Grey and red. And more red than you will ever want to see. Even Hexen 2 which used Quake 1 engine looked better. Or Quake 1, which still used more colors and it was contributing to gritty atmoshpere.

Gameplay isn't exciting either. It's much more slowed-paced. It makes use of more hitscan enemies attacks. It just feels like it promotes more of cover-based tactics. Sure, there are few different enemy types with slightly different attacks, but in the end it still doesn't make a big difference. You peek out, you shoot, you hide from machinegun bullets back around corner. Or from railgun. Quake 1 had Ogres and Fiends, one would spam grenades around room and was often placed in interesting spots, while fiends were dangerous enemies that easily charged at you, all of which making you strafe and navigate, being more interestign to fight against. Quake 2 is just plain not exciting. Even melee enemy, Berserker, isn't threatening here, being slow, attacks while standing, easy to get out of attack reach with a single step, easy to knock down.

On more positive note, Enemy AI was improved. While they don't provide as much of fun as Hexen 2 ones, they still show more life to them. Mostly just ducking here and there. They get covered in blood as you shoot them down and some of the common enemies can even give the last few shots before dying. Don't worry, they don't aim when they do that, just shoot straight, so it's not annoying and looks awesome. Can always gib.

Not sure what to say about equipment. Yes, you got more weapons than before. They got some interesting ideas behind, I like that recoil on Machine Gun, back before recoil was a common thing. You can also choose whether you want to have weapon on left, right or in center, which impacts where shots come from too (it's in multiplayer setting, but affects single as well). And heck, it has railgun. Which even does extra damage on unaware enemies. It's still feels like you have too much ammo and that weapons aren't too specialized in single. But still, nice.

Quake 2 also adds inventory. It wasn't implented good. There aren't so many items to use. Sure, being able to use Quad Damage whenever you want is nice, radiation suit and rebreather help with secrets. But that's about it. It suffers because developers decided that they have to put weapons you have as inventory items as well, making it harder to navigate while bringing nothing. Even worse is that they put grenades between all this mess that you can't select otherwise.
EDIT: Was wrong, grenade are easily selectable with "G" button. Items have other keybinds, but not something I want to always remember.

Bosses are quite meh. You can quad-damage them anyway.

Soundtrack is quite nice. At least great when you listen to it serapately and some memoriable rock. Or whatever genre this is. It gets a bit monotonial after a while. A nice touch is that music suddenly ends when you complete all goals on the level, showing that you got nothing to do there anymore. It somehow ends up being awkward though, when you still got something to do.

Multiplayer on other hand is a big improvement over Quake. Now, it's still old-school and will not interest many, especially seeing how Quake 3 Arena is out. But you got to say that's it's quite a little fun. It's slower-paced, sure. But it finally got balance in weapons. The one who has rocket launcher no longer dominates whole arena, as other weapons are viable alternatives with their own specialization, mostly range difference. Better for those who prefer a bit more thinking and a bit less reflexes. I do have a bad feelign that railgun may end up being a bit too good, penetrating and killing unarmed players in one shot. But I didn't play for long.

And well, I wrote some bad things here, sure. Yes, I think that this game is generic and missable. But you know, it's still a fine generic FPS. With very few bright spots. It's not something I would call a classic, but you can still have fun with it. And it doesn't do anything way too bad in gameplay. No cheap deaths or such to frustrate you. So, feel free to check it out.

This would be the one game I played in its entirety more times than I can remember. From the first time I played it on the PlayStation back in 1999, I come back to it every now and then when I just want to let myself loose. And it feels great every time, no matter the platform - Nintendo 64, PlayStation or PC. Although, many people were disappointed it's not a true sequel to the original Quake - it is the first entry in the Strogg saga.

Some time in the future, the Earth has been invaded by the Strogg, a race of cybernetic aliens, whose past and origins aren't quite clear. They don't take prisoners, they take unwilling recruits. Dead or alive, they will serve as an extension of the ever growing Strogg army. The Space Marine Corps have decided to show the Strogg they won't just sit around while our planet's population is being decimated by the alien forces, and have launched a massive counter-assault on Stroggos, the invaders' home planet (or, at least, their current home planet).

As the operation goes downhill the minute it started, the player assumes control of Bitterman, one of the few marines left alive on the surface of Stroggos. Armed with whatever he finds along the way (and he will find a plethora of weapons), Bitterman must cut his way through Strogg defenses all by himself, and try and bring the Strogg forces down.

The unique atmosphere of the game will keep you on your toes all along, as the Strogg fall under your sights one by one and you complete objectives sent by the Earth command.

The only downside of the Steam version is the lack of the original soundtrack, a very strong heavy metal score composed by Sonic Mayhem, which really gave the game a unique feel. This is something that should really be rectified in an update or a patch, as playing Quake II without the Quake II music is like riding a horse, naked. It just doesn't work. Since the original game read music directly from the CD, I don't think it's such a big problem to have the OST in a compressed format, along with the game. Or at least have the CD image of the game available for those who purchase it, so they can burn it and enjoy the full Quake II experience.

Hello, today I'll review QUAKE II. I'll look at PROS and CONS of it's existence, throw in some fun personal notes and impressions, and then throw down my verdict on whether you should invest money into it.

-----

Firstly, QUAKE II suffers from a very serious problem. It's boring. Sloggy. Tedious. Clunky.

Normally, taking the age into account you can look past all of this and cheerily stroke memories of you getting it for Christmas from your none-the-wiser parents when you were 8 or 12 or however old.

The thing is, this game aged like trash and so did the engine. Though lets get on with a fun section with bullet points!

-
PROS:
It has a story, which is something QUAKE was almost entirely without.

Guns. It sure does have them!

Particle Acceleration. Wow! Those 124MBs of RAM will come in handy.


CONS:
The guns are vomit worthy, in function and appearance.

When bullets don't instantly hit, their speed can be described as a light saunter.

Gray. Brown. Tannish Orange. Gunmetal Gray. Red. There was more color variation in the first Borderlands.

Any thought that went into the level design is completely lost on the mind numbing tedium of actually getting through one.

Everything looks fat and stupid and clunky. Just look at the basic Strogg infantry's run, there's nothing threatening about these enemies.
-

There was a serious problem of not taking advantage of what the engine had to offer. 

Even with Dai-Katana, there was concept and variety with things like weapons and stages. There were also colors and things that could be seen as "interesting to look at". Just look at, say, JonTron's review of it. It looks like shit, but god dammit it's colorful shit.

In all, this game is nothing but a showboat for the QUAKE II engine and should be treated that way.

This is a terrific series, QUAKE is, but this iteration never failed to bore me to quitting not even 2/3rds of the way into a level.

-
SHOULD YOU BUY? THREE SITUATIONS...

1. If you love the QUAKE series, if you've always loved it and played them when you were a wee chitlun then yes, but this review is not made with nostalgia-goggles or whatever edgy term we're using for fond, clouding memories detailing our days of yore. Though I'm not sure why you don't already have several cds or flash disks with it already.

2. No, I say if you're looking for something interesting and fun to challenge yourself with then this most certainly is not the game for you as there are arguably more appropriate things for that. I recommend QUAKE or QUAKE III: Arena, it's predecessor and successor respectively.

3. I also say that if you are new and have an interest in the QUAKE series of games then by god go for it and learn some lore or be completionist or whatever.

---

With that I'm done. 

If you've already disliked this just based on the fact it's a negative review of a game you like. Eat a dick. Eat twenty. Without any milk.

If you disagree and have something coherent to bring to a discussion comment and see if your infallible reason can sway me about giving this game more chances.

Good day.

Quake 2 is simply a classic, and one of few games I've personally mastered. Quite literally, the moment achievements come out on the game, if they ever do, I'll be among the first to get them all.

Quake 2 is basically a game where you infiltrate and alien world in order to kil their leader and make way for a larger-scale attack, while deactivating defense grids and blowing up a giant gun battery. You also kill things.

The game has very little story, delivered in the manual of the game (which i don't think comes with the game), but basically you're a soldier who deploys in a drop pod to the world named Stroggos. Your pod gets hit hugely off-course, and you land in an outpost of not much consequence.
You are totally alone. No buddies, no air-support, all you have is your blaster, and your PDA which give you stat readouts on the area (like how many people are still waiting to die, or how many secrets) but more importantly, your objectives beamed down from the capital ship in orbit into said PDA.

The game is essentially as good as FPS adventure action games get witohut going into arena FPS territory, and is (in my opinion) the only one to do this to date.

The game has level stats exactly like in Duke Nukem 3D, Quake 1 and even Doom 1, and the secrets are always really good and memorizing their locations can become second-nature and are even instrumental on Hard+ difficulty.

Quake 2 is an FPS that can be played mainly as a singleplayer game, but has Multiplayer and even Co-op, and lived in the days when Balancing wasn't even a matter that was at all important in the eyes of Developers.

Multiplayer is essentialy arena-FPS and that's awesome.

The game has 3 mission packs, 2 of which are on Steam (and i think the 3rd is too).

For anyone who likes FPS games that doesn't easy-mode the experience by giving you regeneration, checkpoints, and newly refreshed ammo and weapons at the beginning of every new level, Quake 2 is a must have.

10357364.review: Quake II is a great game that any fan of classic first-person shooters should try. The real star of the show here is the level design. Much like other classic fps games, Quake II sees you running back and forth between places to get keys and do tasks to open up other parts of the level, but where other games did this within the confines of a single area, Quake II strings together several interconnected maps, making players traverse massive areas that are essentially levels within levels. Usually you will be tasked to do something in one map, then return to another to recieve the payoff. This sounds like it would make it easy for players to get lost, and while I did find myself confused at times, the maps have a great flow that usually pushes you in the right direction. Overall, Quake II has a great scope that you don't find in many shooters even today. The level design  would be meaningless of course if the players didn't have anything to fight against, and Quake II delivers in this regard. The weapons are meaty and satisfying, and enemies to use them on are plentiful. If I had to say something negative about Quake II, it would be that the environments and enemies aren't as crazy and bizarre as those found in Doom and Quake 1, and there really isn't much variation in the types of locales you'll see (pretty much everything is orange, factory type locations). Enemies are also noticeably easier to fight than in previous Id Software games, being slower to respond and not as aggressive, but they do pose a challenge in numbers and are still very enjoyable to fight. Even though it's not quite as crazy as its predecessors, Quake II is still a great game that's stays fun from start to finish (campaign time was about 9 hours).

I have a soft spot for Quake II - it was the first FPS game I ever played online, way back on our old 56k router. And it was playable at those speeds, too!

Quake II is a classic shooter. There's no hand-holding here - you're plopped in the middle of a war-zone with nothing but your pistol and wits to get you started. Enemies are plentiful and in some instances, tough. And if you don't do some exploration to find extra ammo and armor, you'll find yourself in trouble quickly.

The graphics don't look too amazing when set against 2013 standards, but they certainly deserve to be appreciated, for a game originally released in 1997. Sound is sparse, a bit like what you'll find in games like Doom, but without the constant ambient music.

I enjoy playing this game every now and then for a little nostalgia, but I usually end up playing for longer than I thought I would, just because the simplified, raw experience can be so much fun.

163109.review:
Quake 2 was created by id Software, and released on November 11th, 1997.  It’s a first-person shooter, and was a pioneer of the genre at its release.  Many games today still use some of the multiplayer functions that were founded in Quake 2.

Quake 2 was the first first-person shooter that I played more than any other.  It was the first online multiplayer game that I played, it was the first time I used the handle “KoreRat”, and the first time I downloaded extra content for a game.  Quake 2 was a lot of firsts for me, so I’d be lying if I said I’m not a bit partial to it.

To start, there are mods for Q2 that bump up the graphics to look more in the area of Quake 3 Arena, along with many other additions.

The game starts; you are part of a massive invasion force attacking the Strogg home planet, Stroggos. After getting hit by one of your comrades, you find yourself heading in a different direction.  But luck is with you, when an unknown gun opens up on your unit and you are the only solider left in the force. Crash landing in a base outpost, you are quickly given orders to rendezvous with other squads.

Playing through Q2 again for the first time in a few years was a very reminiscent experience for me.  I found that I still remember where all the secrets were, and all the spots where the Strogg’s jump out at as you pass.  Along with remembering all the times I had played online deathmatch and capture the flag.  A lot of good memories with this game, and perhaps that is why I score Q2 so high.  It’s not just a great game on its own but, for me at least, it brings about a lot of memories of late night gaming.  This is one of the foundation games that really brought about online multiplayer to what it is today.  Without Quake, Doom, Quake 2, and Unreal the entire gaming landscape would be different.

Two mission packs were made for Quake 2, The Reckoning and Ground Zero.  I played these next.  They both add some new weapons and enemies.  They both have a similar story to the main game, wherein you get separated from your squad on entry, they die, and it’s up to you.  Between the two I prefer Ground Zero more.  The Reckoning feels too rushed and almost tries to hard to be as good.  It also reuses The Makron for the final fight.  Ground Zero on the other hand switches it up on you a bit, with a new final boss, The Black Widow, and having you go in disguise for a short while.

Over all, I would say that even after fifteen plus years Quake 2 still holds it’s own with many games out today.  If your looking for a great frag fest or a taste of where modern games started, you definitely want to check out Quake 2.

2205951.review: Quake II definitely lacks the freshness and excitement of its predecessor. Rather than sticking with the peculiarly medieval-ish look of Quake, Quake II attempts to switch things up...by going back to the space marine idiom. With less-satisfying weapons/combat than Quake, and a VERY slow start (the first 5 or 6 maps are a generic slog to get through), Quake II is unquestionably an inferior sequel. HOWEVER, in the interest of seeing it through, I soldiered on (SO NOBLE), and eventually found myself enjoying the latter half of the game. The maps get more varied and interesting (or else my senses gradually dulled to the point where I found them to be), and it finishes much stronger than it started. Not quite a full-on recommendation, I know, but if it's on the cheap, pick it up -- if for no other reason than to experience the first (of many?) flawed id Software shooter.
